questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with a fever and a sore throat. Upon examination, he is found to have red, swollen eyes and small blisters on his upper respiratory tract. Laboratory tests confirm an infection with a DNA virus that is non-enveloped. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the virus?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a single-stranded DNA (ssDNA) virus.

options.label: B
options.text: The virus is icosahedral in shape.

options.label: C
options.text: Conjunctivitis is typically caused by type 17 D adenovirus.

options.label: D
options.text: Haemorrhagic cystitis is caused by serotype 40 & 41.

questions.correct_answer: B. The virus is icosahedral in shape.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) The virus is icosahedral in shape.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Adenoviruses are not ssDNA viruses ; they contain double-stranded DNA.
  • • Option
  • • A.
  • • Adenoviruses are not ssDNA viruses
  • • Option C. Type 17 adenovirus can cause respiratory illness , but it is not the only type associated with conjunctivitis.
  • • Option
  • • C.
  • • Type 17 adenovirus can cause respiratory illness
  • • Option D. Serotypes 11 and 21 are more commonly associated with hemorrhagic cystitis. Adenovirus types 40 and 41 are typically linked to gastroenteritis (especially in children)
  • • Option
  • • D.
  • • 11
  • • 21
  • • 40
  • • 41
  • • gastroenteritis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ref : Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med Microbiology 1/e p449-50,2/e p467-468

questions.text: Identify the suturing technique in the image.
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Horizontal mattress

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman has had abdominal pain for the past 3 days. On physical examination, there are no abnormal findings. Upper GI endoscopy is performed and the gastric mucosa has the appearance depicted in the image shown below. Release of which of the following chemical mediators is most likely to produce this appearance?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Prostaglandins play a crucial role in maintaining the protective mucosal barrier in the stomach. Deficiency of prostaglandins, often due to NSAID use, can lead to gastric mucosal damage, including erosions and ulcerations. Understanding the role of prostaglandins in gastric mucosal protection is important for diagnosing and managing conditions related to gastric mucosal damage.
  • ➤ Prostaglandins play a crucial role in maintaining the protective mucosal barrier in the stomach.
  • ➤ Deficiency of prostaglandins, often due to NSAID use, can lead to gastric mucosal damage, including erosions and ulcerations.
  • ➤ Understanding the role of prostaglandins in gastric mucosal protection is important for diagnosing and managing conditions related to gastric mucosal damage.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the office for evaluation of absent menses. The patient had a vaginal delivery 4 months ago and has not yet had a menstrual period. Her postpartum course was complicated by a retained placenta and postpartum hemorrhage that required a blood transfusion and emergency suction and sharp curettage. At her postpartum visit 2 months ago, the patient was given a prescription for combination oral contraceptive pills; she has had no vaginal bleeding or spotting during her week of placebo pills. Prior to this pregnancy, she had regular monthly menstrual cycles with 34 days of moderate bleeding. The patient has had increased fatigue since returning to work. The patient had no headaches, galactorrhea, or hot flashes. Vital signs are normal. BMI is 31 kg/m². Pelvic examination shows clear vaginal discharge throughout the vault and a well-rugated vagina. The uterus is small and anteverted, and both ovaries are small and non-tender. Urine pregnancy test is negative. FSH and TSH levels are normal. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's clinical presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Asherman syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To recognize Asherman syndrome as a potential complication following uterine surgery, especially after procedures like dilation and curettage that are performed in the context of retained placenta and postpartum hemorrhage. Asherman syndrome can lead to amenorrhea and infertility due to intrauterine adhesions that form as a result of the surgical intervention.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the physician complaining of heartburn and black, tarry stools. He states that he has been eating much less than usual, although he still manages to drink at least one beer per day, which he reports having done for the past 20 years. On physical examination, the patient exhibits diffuse tenderness and guarding over the entire epigastric area. Serum levels of which of the following substances are likely to be elevated in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Gastrin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective is to understand the role of gastrin in the pathophysiology of peptic ulcer disease. Gastrin stimulates gastric acid secretion, which can contribute to the development of peptic ulcers, especially in the presence of risk factors such as chronic alcohol consumption. Recognizing the clinical presentation of peptic ulcer disease and understanding the underlying physiological mechanisms are crucial for diagnosis and management.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to an urgent care centre by his parents due to a rash. The patient awoke yesterday with a rash on his trunk, but his mother says that "it now seems particularly red in his underarms and private area". Over the last 2 days, he has also had headache, fever, and sore throat. He has no allergies, and his immunizations are up to date. Temperature is 38.3⁰C (101⁰F), blood pressure is 112/70 mm Hg, pulse is 108/min, and respiratory rate is 20/min. The patient is tired-appearing but playful and in no acute distress. Examination reveals a fine, erythematous, papular rash with a rough texture on the anterior trunk. The rash appears more concentrated in the axillae and groin and blanches with pressure. Tender, shotty, anterior cervical lymphadenopathy is present, and the posterior oropharynx is erythematous with tonsillar exudates and soft palatal petechiae. The father adds, "Two kids in his class had the same symptoms, and now their skin is peeling". What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Scarlet fever

questions.text: An 18-month-old boy is brought to the clinic because he has been pulling on his ears. Two weeks ago, the patient was taken to an urgent care centre for fever and irritability and was found to have acute otitis media of the right ear. He completed the prescribed course of amoxicillin, with resolution of symptoms. However, for the past few days, the patient has been tugging at both of his ears, and his parents are concerned that he may have another ear infection. Temperature is 36.8⁰C (98.2⁰F). On otoscopic examination, air-fluid levels are visible posterior to both tympanic membranes, which appear translucent and gray. Pneumatic insufflation demonstrates reduced mobility of tympanic membranes bilaterally. Both external ear canals are clear. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Observation and follow up

questions.text: A child presents with complaints of itching over scalp. On examination, a patch of hair loss, with redness is noted as shown in the image below. Which of the following investigations would help to diagnose the most probable diagnosis in this child?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a child with an itchy scalp and a patch of hair loss, a KOH mount of the scalp can help diagnose a fungal infection, often the most likely cause. This test is simple, quick, and a good first step in such cases.
  • ➤ For a child with an itchy scalp and a patch of hair loss, a KOH mount of the scalp can help diagnose a fungal infection, often the most likely cause.

questions.text: In a dramatic turn of events at a large industrial plant, a worker is found lying motionless near a high-voltage electrical panel. The emergency response team rushes to the scene, where they find no visible injuries but the worker is unresponsive and without apparent signs of life. Which of the following scenarios is most likely to result in a state of suspended animation, where the victim might appear lifeless but is still alive?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Electrocution

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Suspended animation is when an organism’s bodily functions, like breathing and heartbeat, are drastically slowed down or paused as seen in electrocution.
  • • Suspended animation
  • • Suspended animation
  • • Suspended animation is a condition in which vital signs of life (heart beat and respiration) are not detected by routine clinical methods, as the functions are interrupted for some time or are reduced to a minimum.
  • • Mechanism: The metabolic rate is greatly reduced so that the requirement of the individual cell for oxygen is satisfied through the dissolved oxygen in body fluids
  • • Other options
  • • Other options
  • • B. Strangulation/ hangingC. Firearm injury and D. Burn: suspended animation is not usually seen in these conditions.

questions.text: A 5-year-old, previously healthy girl is brought to the emergency department due to lethargy and altered mental status. The patient was in her usual state of health until 5 days ago, when she developed fever, malaise, headache, cough, and nasal discharge. The fever resolved with over-the-counter medications, and the patient was feeling better until this morning, when she developed nausea, vomiting, and lethargy. She has no chronic medical conditions and takes no prescription medications. Temperature is 36.8⁰C (98.2⁰F), blood pressure is 98/60 mm Hg, pulse is 110/min, and respirations are 20/min. The patient is not oriented to person, place, or time. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Hepatomegaly is present; there is no splenomegaly. CT scan of the head reveals diffuse cerebral edema. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's imaging findings?
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Hyperammonemia

questions.text: In the management of a treatment-experienced HIV-infected patient with multidrug-resistant HIV-1, which specific antiretroviral drug combination, including cobicistat, is recommended to achieve optimal viral suppression while minimizing potential drug interactions and side effects?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Darunavir

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective is to familiarize individuals with different antiretroviral drugs used in the management of HIV/AIDS, particularly their mechanisms of action. Understanding these mechanisms is essential for healthcare professionals to make informed decisions about drug combinations and regimens for HIV-infected patients.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman notes a lump in her left breast while taking a shower. The nurse practitioner palpates a 3 cm firm, irregular, non-movable mass in the upper outer quadrant of her left breast on physical examination. A fine needle aspiration of this mass is performed, and cytologically the cells are consistent with infiltrating ductal carcinoma. The mass is removed with lumpectomy along with an axillary sentinel lymph node sampling. Which of the following findings will best predict a better prognosis for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Tumor cells are strongly estrogen receptor positive

options.label: B
options.text: No metastases in the sampled lymph nodes

options.label: C
options.text: Flow cytometric analysis with aneuploidy and a high S-phase

options.label: D
options.text: One relative who had a similar type of breast cancer

questions.correct_answer: B. No metastases in the sampled lymph nodes
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) No metastases in the sampled lymph nodes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Estrogen receptor (ER) positivity is an important prognostic factor in breast cancer, with strongly ER-positive tumors associated with a better prognosis. The absence of lymph node metastases is a strong predictor of a better prognosis in breast cancer, indicating a lower stage and a lower risk of recurrence. Certain tumor characteristics, such as aneuploidy and high proliferation rate, are associated with a worse prognosis. Family history of breast cancer influences overall risk but does not directly predict an individual's prognosis.
  • ➤ Estrogen receptor (ER) positivity is an important prognostic factor in breast cancer, with strongly ER-positive tumors associated with a better prognosis.
  • ➤ The absence of lymph node metastases is a strong predictor of a better prognosis in breast cancer, indicating a lower stage and a lower risk of recurrence.
  • ➤ Certain tumor characteristics, such as aneuploidy and high proliferation rate, are associated with a worse prognosis.
  • ➤ Family history of breast cancer influences overall risk but does not directly predict an individual's prognosis.

questions.text: A 64-year-old smoker visits his primary care physician because of recent weight gain and worsening coughs. On physical examination, the physician notes that the patient’s extremities are thinner than before, while his waist is increased in girth. The patient also has a pad of adipose tissue at the base of his neck and purple striae on his abdomen. The physician decides to run some blood tests and obtain an x-ray of the chest, which shows a central lesion. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Small cell carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective is to recognize the clinical features of paraneoplastic syndromes associated with lung cancer, particularly small cell lung cancer. Small cell lung cancer can produce ectopic ACTH, leading to Cushing's syndrome, characterized by weight gain, fat redistribution, muscle wasting, and skin changes. Identifying these signs and symptoms in the context of lung cancer can aid in the diagnosis and prompt further investigation for appropriate management.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman with a 2-year history of infertility presents to her gynecologist for a follow-up visit. She has been diagnosed with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) based on oligomenorrhea, hyperandrogenism, and polycystic ovaries on ultrasound. Her past medical history is unremarkable, and she has no significant family history of metabolic or reproductive disorders. Her BMI is 32 kg/m². She has been on clomiphene citrate for the last 3 months without achieving ovulation. Her fasting glucose and insulin levels suggest insulin resistance. The patient is eager to conceive and inquires about additional treatments that could improve her response to clomiphene. Which of the following medications can be added to improve the clomiphene response in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Metformin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Metformin administered to women with PCOS, increased the frequency of spontaneous ovulation, menstrual cyclicity, and ovulatory response to Clomiphene citrate.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of recurrent epistaxis. Every morning, the patient wakes up with significant nasal congestion; when he blows his nose, he often sees crusting and blood clots in the tissue. Afterward, his nose frequently (several times a week) starts bleeding. It stops within 5 minutes of pinching his nasal alae. Medical history includes obesity, hypertension, and obstructive sleep apnea treated with continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP). Vital signs are within normal limits. On examination, the nose has bilateral crusting with excoriations on both sides of the nasal septum, but there is no bleeding. Which of the following is the most appropriate step in management of this patient's condition?
questions.explanation: Ans. C) CPAP humidification

questions.text: A 29-years-old pregnant female's routine investigations showed VDRL positive with 1:16 titres. TPHA was also positive. The pregnant female was adequately treated with injection benzathine penicillin. What is the next step of management for the baby?

options.label: A
options.text: Give injection aqueous penicillin to baby

options.label: B
options.text: Perform serum VDRL of the baby

options.label: C
options.text: Perform CSF VDRL of the baby

questions.correct_answer: B. Perform serum VDRL of the baby
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Perform serum VDRL of the baby

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective is to screen a newborn for congenital syphilis when the mother has a history of the infection, which is done by performing a serum VDRL test. It's critical for medical students to understand the importance of screening and the potential implications of congenital syphilis for appropriate clinical management.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of occasional episodes of chest tightness, wheezing, and cough. The symptoms are often mild and resolve spontaneously. He has been healthy otherwise. His respiration rate is 13/min. The lungs are clear on auscultation. Cardiac examination and chest x-ray show no abnormalities. Which of the following agents is most appropriate to treat acute episodes in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Salbutamol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To understand the pharmacological management of acute asthma episodes. The primary goal in an acute asthma attack is the rapid reversal of airway constriction, for which short-acting β2-adrenergic agonists like salbutamol are most effective. Other medications, such as inhaled corticosteroids and mast cell stabilizers, are crucial in the long-term management of asthma to reduce chronic inflammation and prevent future attacks but are not appropriate for immediate relief of acute symptoms. Anticholinergics like ipratropium can be used in certain cases but are generally less effective than β2-agonists for acute asthma symptoms.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman is brought to the office by her husband due to anxiety. The patient had an uncomplicated vaginal delivery a week ago and was discharged on postpartum day 2. Her husband notes that she was "really nervous" after returning home. The patient would watch the infant overnight to check for respirations and followed a strict feeding regimen. At the first well-child visit, she expressed concerns about the newborn's weight but was told he had surpassed his birth weight and was healthy and doing well. Despite this reassurance, the patient has continued to worry. For the past 2 days, she has been pacing around the house, sleeping poorly, and eating minimally. This morning, the husband found the patient mixing protein powder with formula due to concern that the infant was "shrinking." The patient says, "I know my baby is sick, but the doctors won't tell me the truth. They're trying to hurt my baby." She has no psychiatric history. Vital signs and physical examination are within normal limits. The patient appears tearful and exhausted. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Postpartum psychosis

questions.text: You notice the below shown instrument being used in the gynecology OT. Which surgery would this instrument be used in?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Total laparoscopic hysterectomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ This is a uterine manipulator Uterine manipulator is used to assist movements of the uterus in laparoscopic surgeries, particularly in laparoscopic hysterectomies.
  • ➤ This is a uterine manipulator
  • ➤ This is a uterine manipulator
  • ➤ Uterine manipulator is used to assist movements of the uterus in laparoscopic surgeries, particularly in laparoscopic hysterectomies.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man with a history of hyperlipidemia and multiple transient ischemic attacks presents to the emergency department after two hours of left-sided weakness in his upper extremity and face. After a CT of the head shows no evidence of intracranial hemorrhage, a fibrinolytic enzyme is administered. Two hours later, the man develops bleeding from his gums as well as several large subcutaneous ecchymoses. Which of the following drugs could stop this man’s bleeding?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Aminocaproic acid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective is to understand the management of bleeding complications associated with fibrinolytic therapy. Aminocaproic acid is an anti-fibrinolytic agent that can be used to counteract the effects of fibrinolytic drugs and stop bleeding by inhibiting plasminogen activation and the subsequent breakdown of fibrin clots. Recognizing the appropriate use of anti-fibrinolytic agents in the context of bleeding due to fibrinolytic therapy is crucial for patient safety and effective treatment.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the clinic with complaints of high fever, a burning sensation during urination, and lower abdominal pain. She has no significant past medical history and reports no recent sexual activity. A diagnosis of uncomplicated acute cystitis is made based on her clinical presentation and initial urinalysis results. Which of the following urinalysis findings is inconsistent with a typical diagnosis of uncomplicated acute cystitis?

options.label: A
options.text: Escherichia coli count of <10 3 colony-forming units per millilitre (CFU/mL)

options.label: B
options.text: An average of 1 pus cell per high power field (HPF)

options.label: C
options.text: The presence of one rod-shaped bacterium per high power field

questions.correct_answer: A. Escherichia coli count of <10 3 colony-forming units per millilitre (CFU/mL)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Escherichia coli count of <103colony-forming units per millilitre (CFU/mL)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The uncomplicated acute cystitis, an E. coli count of ≥10 5 CFU/mL is considered diagnostic.
  • ➤ The uncomplicated acute cystitis, an E. coli count of ≥10 5 CFU/mL is considered diagnostic.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents to the emergency room with symptoms of extreme stress and anxiety. He reports a recent traumatic event and is experiencing a "fight or flight" response. Which of the following statements regarding the effect of strong sympathetic activation on the kidneys is most accurate for this patient?
questions.correct_answer: D. Decrease in Glomerular Filtration Rate
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Decrease in Glomerular Filtration Rate

  • ➤ Understand the physiological response of the kidneys to strong sympathetic activation and how it can impact renal function .

questions.text: Moynihan’s hump is an anatomical variation with respect to which of the below structures?
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Right hepatic artery

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with fragile skin, arrives at the Dermatology OPD. On examination, it was observed that he has bullae which are healing with scarring, and erosions on the extensor surfaces of his elbows, hands, and knees. Direct immunofluorescence (DIF) microscopy findings revealed antibodies against type VII collagen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient presenting with fragile skin, scarring bullae on extensor surfaces, and DIF findings showing antibodies against type VII collagen, the most likely diagnosis is Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita.
  • ➤ Ref: Rook’s textbook of dermatology, 9 th Edition, Chapter 50, page no. 50.41

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after being found unconscious in her apartment by her roommate. First responders found empty bottles of acetaminophen and clonazepam as well as a note on the floor beside the patient. The patient had been increasingly isolative in recent months and hired a lawyer to help write a will last week. She has a long history of episodic sadness and despair dating back to her adolescence. During these periods of sadness, the patient often needs to be reminded to eat, get out of bed, and take care of herself; on 3 occasions, she was hospitalized after attempting to hang herself. Temperature is 37.2⁰C (99⁰F), blood pressure is 108/76 mm Hg, pulse is 88/min, and respirations are 12/min. She is somnolent but arousable. The remainder of the examination is within normal limits. Which of the following abnormalities is most likely to be present in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Diffuse 3-Hz spike and wave discharges on electroencephalogram

options.label: B
options.text: Generalized slowing and periodic sharp wave complexes on electroencephalogram

options.label: C
options.text: Low concentration of hypocretin (orexin) in the Cerebrospinal fluid

options.label: D
options.text: Low concentration of 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid in the cerebrospinal fluid

questions.correct_answer: D. Low concentration of 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid in the cerebrospinal fluid
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Low concentration of 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid in the cerebrospinal fluid

questions.text: Eutectic mixture of local anesthetics (EMLA cream) is sometimes used to numb the skin before attempting an intravenous access in pediatric patients. Which of the following local anesthetics is combined with prilocaine to produce this cream?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lidocaine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective is to understand the composition and clinical application of EMLA cream in pediatric medicine. Knowing that EMLA cream contains lidocaine and prilocaine, helps healthcare professionals choose an appropriate topical anesthetic for minimizing pain associated with needle punctures or minor surgical procedures in children. Awareness of the different types of local anesthetics, their characteristics, and uses is crucial for safe and effective patient care in various medical settings.
  • ➤ The educational objective is to understand the composition and clinical application of EMLA cream in pediatric medicine.
  • ➤ Knowing that EMLA cream contains lidocaine and prilocaine, helps healthcare professionals choose an appropriate topical anesthetic for minimizing pain associated with needle punctures or minor surgical procedures in children.
  • ➤ Awareness of the different types of local anesthetics, their characteristics, and uses is crucial for safe and effective patient care in various medical settings.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman presents to the emergency department following a motor vehicle collision. She did not sustain any serious physical injuries, but she appears drowsy and states that she is feeling very sleepy. Emergency medical staff collected several open medication bottles from the floor of her automobile. Although the contents of two of the bottles could not be determined, the patient’s recently filled bottle of diazepam was almost empty. The patient quickly becomes unresponsive and stops breathing. Administration of which of the following agents will reverse these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Flumazenil

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective is to recognize flumazenil as the appropriate reversal agent for benzodiazepine overdose. Flumazenil works by competitively inhibiting benzodiazepines at their binding site on the GABA-A receptor, which can reverse the central nervous system depressant effects of benzodiazepines, including sedation and respiratory depression. It is crucial to choose the specific antidote based on the type of drug overdose to effectively reverse the symptoms.

questions.text: A 1-day-old boy is in the neonatal intensive care unit due to congenital anomalies noted at birth. The infant was born vaginally at 36 weeks gestation to a 25-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 2, who declined prenatal testing and reported decreased fetal movement in the week preceding delivery. The infant was not latching well for the first 24 hours but has urinated and stooled. Examination shows a small face and jaw with a prominence on the back of the head. The oral mucosa is pink, but the hands and feet are mildly cyanotic. There are no skin creases on the palmar aspect of the digits. There is overlapping of the fingers bilaterally along with convexity of bilateral soles and limited hip abduction. A murmur at the left lower sternal border is heard on auscultation. Which of the following cardiovascular abnormalities is most likely present in this patient?
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD)

questions.text: A 32-year-old man was found deceased under suspicious circumstances in a rented apartment in Mumbai. The case has drawn significant media attention, and there is pressure on authorities to conduct a thorough investigation. According to the Indian legal process, which type of inquest will be done in India for such cases?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Police Inquest

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In India, the commonest inquest is police inquest. Other than police inquest, the other inquest is magistrate inquest which is done in few conditions like Dowry death, exhumation, and custodial deaths. Coroner’s inquest and medical examiner system are not done in India.

questions.text: Identify the incorrectly matched pair with respect to its nerve supply of the marked structures in the given image.
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Glossopharyngeal nerve

questions.text: A 58-year-old male with a history of hypercholesterolemia is enrolled in a clinical study to evaluate the efficacy of a new statin medication. The research team records his fasting cholesterol levels, which are notably elevated. He is then started on the statin therapy, and his cholesterol levels are re-measured after 6 weeks of consistent medication use. The primary aim of the study is to determine the statistical significance of the change in his cholesterol levels before and after the intervention. Given this scenario, which statistical test is most appropriate for analyzing the data?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Paired t-test

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents to her gynecologist with oligomenorrhea. On examination, she is found to have enlarged, non-tender ovaries bilaterally. The patient’s body mass index is 31 kg/m². What other symptom or finding is this patient likely to have?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hirsutism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective is to recognize the clinical features of Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS), which include menstrual irregularities, polycystic ovaries on ultrasound, and signs of hyperandrogenism such as hirsutism. PCOS is often associated with obesity and insulin resistance, contributing to its pathophysiology. Understanding these associations is crucial for the diagnosis and management of PCOS.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents, 30 minutes after having a generalized tonic-clonic seizure while playing in a soccer game. She currently takes no medications. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. After further testing including 24-hour continuous EEG monitoring, carbamazepine is prescribed. This patient’s use of additional medications should be monitored because of which of the following changes in drug disposition after starting pharmacotherapy?
questions.correct_answer: D. Increased metabolism by the liver
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Increased metabolism by the liver

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key educational objective here is to understand the enzyme-inducing effects of carbamazepine on hepatic metabolism. Carbamazepine can increase the metabolism of various drugs by inducing cytochrome P450 enzymes in the liver. This effect necessitates close monitoring when carbamazepine is used in combination with other medications, as it may reduce their effectiveness by increasing their metabolic clearance.

questions.text: Patients with hyperthyroidism have several options to treat their disease, including subtotal thyroidectomy and radioactive ablation. When a patient is unwilling or unable to undergo these procedures, pharmacological therapy is often pursued. One particular medication inhibits the conversion of iodide to iodine and inhibits the organification of iodine with tyrosine. Which of the following is an additional mechanism of action of this drug?

options.label: B
options.text: Binding to and blocking the iodide transport mechanism of thyroid follicular cells

options.label: C
options.text: Binding to intracellular nuclear receptors of peripheral tissue and activating genes

options.label: D
options.text: Blocking the peripheral conversion of thyroxine to triiodothyronine

questions.correct_answer: D. Blocking the peripheral conversion of thyroxine to triiodothyronine
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Blocking the peripheral conversion of thyroxine to triiodothyronine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective is to understand the mechanisms of action of thionamide medications, such as propylthiouracil (PTU) and methimazole, used in the treatment of hyperthyroidism. While both inhibit the synthesis of thyroid hormones by blocking the iodination of tyrosine residues in thyroglobulin and the coupling of iodotyrosines, PTU has the additional mechanism of blocking the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3. This understanding is crucial for selecting appropriate therapy in the management of hyperthyroidism, especially considering the specific clinical scenario and patient preferences.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman has noted enlargement of her anterior neck region over the past 8 months. There is diffuse, symmetrical thyroid enlargement without tenderness. The chest radiograph is normal. Fine needle aspiration of the thyroid yields cells consistent with a neoplasm. Laboratory studies show that she is euthyroid, but her serum ionized calcium is elevated. She is taken to surgery and frozen sections of several thyroid masses show a malignant neoplasm composed of polygonal cells in nests. A thyroidectomy is performed. Immunostaining for calcitonin of the permanent sections is positive, and the neoplasm has an amyloid stroma with Congo red staining. Which of the following neoplasms is she most likely to have?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) arises from the parafollicular C cells of the thyroid gland and is associated with elevated serum calcitonin levels. MTC may present with thyroid enlargement and is characterized by an amyloid stroma and positive calcitonin immunostaining. It can occur sporadically or as part of familial syndromes, such as multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN2).

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman with a 17-year history of type 1 diabetes mellitus and progressive renal failure is being considered for dialysis. Laboratory studies show normocytic, normochromic anemia. Which of the following medications is most appropriate to treat the anemia in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Erythropoietin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with chronic kidney disease, the most common cause of normocytic, normochromic anemia is a deficiency in erythropoietin production by the kidneys. The most appropriate treatment in such cases is the administration of synthetic erythropoietin (erythropoiesis-stimulating agents) to stimulate red blood cell production. Other supplements like folic acid, folinic acid, and vitamin B1 may be important in specific contexts but are not the primary treatment for anemia associated with CKD.

questions.text: A small town's healthcare system is evaluating the capacity of its mortuary. Over the last year, the town reported 600 deaths. questions.text: In a comprehensive study conducted at a regional hospital, 200 patients were screened for Glaucoma using a new advanced imaging technique. To validate the imaging results, all patients subsequently underwent a detailed ophthalmologic examination, which is considered the gold standard for diagnosing Glaucoma. Out of 80 patients who tested positive in the imaging screening, 64 were confirmed to have Glaucoma during the examination. Among the 120 patients who tested negative in the screening, 96 were confirmed not to have Glaucoma in the examination. Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 25-year-old medical student presents to a health clinic with fatigue, a sore throat, and chills. His temperature is 101.6°F (38.7°C). Findings on physical examination are significant for a red oropharynx with exudate and tender enlarged lymph nodes. A rapid strep test is positive for Streptococcus-induced pharyngitis. The physician plans to prescribe penicillin, but the patient reports that the last time he took penicillin, he experienced severe airway swelling and difficulty breathing that required hospitalization. Which of the following is the best choice for treating this patient, given his penicillin allergy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Azithromycin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key educational objective is to understand the management of bacterial pharyngitis in the context of a patient with a penicillin allergy. When treating bacterial infections in patients allergic to penicillin, it is important to select antibiotics with minimal cross-reactivity and appropriate spectrum of activity. Macrolides like azithromycin are effective alternatives for treating Streptococcus-induced pharyngitis in patients with a penicillin allergy. It's also important to consider the severity of the allergic reaction to penicillin when considering a β-lactam alternative, reserving broad-spectrum antibiotics for more severe or resistant infections to avoid the development of antibiotic resistance.

questions.text: A 68-year-old hospitalized woman is evaluated due to decreased vision in the left eye. The patient has a history of advanced ovarian cancer and has been treated with combination chemotherapy. Three weeks ago, she was admitted to the hospital with small bowel obstruction. There was no improvement with non-operative management, so she underwent exploratory laparotomy and bowel resection 14 days ago. The post-operative course was complicated by an anastomotic leak. The patient is receiving total parenteral nutrition and piperacillin-tazobactam. Over the past 2 days, she has had floaters and progressive blurring of the vision in the left eye. The patient reports no eye pain or headache. Temperature is 38⁰C (100.4⁰F), blood pressure is 122/80 mm Hg, and pulse is 96/min. Left eye visual acuity is decreased, and fundoscopy reveals fluffy, yellow-white chorioretinal lesions with ill-defined borders. The central venous catheter site has no erythema or tenderness. There is no discharge from the abdominal incisions. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's ocular symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Fungal endophthalmitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key educational point here is recognizing the risk factors and clinical presentation of fungal endophthalmitis. Patients with a compromised immune system, recent surgery, or central venous catheters are at increased risk. Fundoscopic examination revealing characteristic fluffy, yellow-white chorioretinal lesions is crucial for diagnosis. Prompt recognition and treatment are important due to the potential for severe vision loss.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman, P2L2, is in the postpartum unit after an uncomplicated spontaneous vaginal delivery with involuntary dribbling of small amounts of urine. It has been 6 hours since the delivery and the patient has been unable to empty her bladder. During labor, she received epidural anesthesia for severe pain with contractions and her bladder was intermittently catheterized. The patient has no chronic medical conditions, takes no medications, and has no known allergies. Vital signs are normal. Examination shows a firm uterine fundus palpable at the umbilicus and fullness and tenderness above the pubic symphysis. The perineum and vagina are edematous but without lacerations. Sensation is intact in the lower extremities, but the patient is unable to void a measurable amount. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Urethral catheterization

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To recognize and manage acute urinary retention in the postpartum period. Urethral catheterization is the immediate and standard treatment to relieve retention, prevent bladder over distension, and avoid further complications. It is important to assess and monitor postpartum women for urinary retention, especially those who have had regional anesthesia during labor.

questions.text: Dr. Patel is reviewing the imaging studies of a 52-year-old male patient, Mr. Ram, who has been suffering from episodic severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting for several years. The patient has a history of heavy alcohol use and recurrent episodes of acute pancreatitis. Recently, Mr. Ram has reported increased frequency and intensity of his abdominal pain, accompanied by weight loss and diarrhea, prompting further evaluation. A contrast-enhanced abdominal CT scan is performed, which shows diffuse pancreatic parenchymal atrophy, extensive intraductal and parenchymal calcifications, and a dilated pancreatic duct with irregular contours. There are no signs of acute inflammation or necrosis. Based on the patient's history and imaging findings, Dr. Patel is considering the diagnosis of a chronic pancreatic condition. Considering Mr. Ram's clinical history and the CT scan findings, which of the following diagnoses is most consistent with the imaging results?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Chronic relapsing pancreatitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective is to recognize the imaging findings and clinical presentation of chronic relapsing pancreatitis, which include diffuse pancreatic parenchymal atrophy, intraductal and parenchymal calcifications, and a dilated pancreatic duct with irregular contours. The condition is often associated with a history of heavy alcohol use and recurrent episodes of acute pancreatitis.

options.label: B

questions.correct_answer: C. Located between 1 cm above and 2 cm below GE junction
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Located between 1 cm above and 2 cm below GE junction

questions.text: A 60-year-old farmer presents with pulmonary symptoms including a productive cough and chest pain. A CT scan reveals a cavitary lesion in the upper lobe of the right lung. A sputum sample is obtained, and microscopy shows hyphal elements that fragment into rectangular arthroconidia. Which of the following types of fungal spores is most likely observed under the microscope?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Arthrospores

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ SPORES PRODUCED BY MEDICALLY IMPORTANT FUNGI
  • ➤ SPORES PRODUCED BY MEDICALLY IMPORTANT FUNGI

questions.text: Class I antiarrhythmics are sodium channel blockers that slow or block cardiac conduction, especially in depolarized cells. Which of the following antiarrhythmics will increase both the action potential and the effective refractory period?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Procainamide

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective is to understand the classification of Class I antiarrhythmic drugs and their effects on the action potential duration and effective refractory period. Class IA agents, like procainamide, not only block sodium channels but also have a moderate potassium channel blocking effect, leading to an increase in both the action potential duration and the effective refractory period. This is in contrast to Class IB and IC agents, which do not have this combined effect.

questions.text: A 74-year-old woman presents with a 2-year history of a painless, progressively enlarging mass in the central aspect of the upper eyelid. This has resulted in distortion of the eyelid margin and loss of eyelashes. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Basal cell carcinoma

questions.text: A 24-year-old G2P1 woman at 39 weeks’ gestation presents with painful uterine contractions. She also complains of minimal vaginal blood mixed with some mucus. Which of the following describes the most likely etiology of her bleeding?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Bloody show

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective is to understand that bloody show is a common and normal occurrence towards the end of pregnancy or during early labor, characterized by minimal vaginal bleeding mixed with mucus, signifying cervical dilation and effacement. It is important to differentiate it from other causes of antepartum hemorrhage, such as placenta previa, placental abruption, and vasa previa, based on the clinical presentation.

questions.text: During a training session in forensic medicine, a resident learns about the importance of analyzing the vitreous humor in determining the post-mortem interval. Which constituent of the vitreous humor is most helpful in accurately estimating the post-mortem interval?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) K

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A steady rise in the potassium values occur in the vitreous humour after death up to 100 hours.

questions.text: An 18-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department after having a seizure in day care. The staff reports that "she suddenly fell down and started shaking," but they also note that the patient has seemed quieter and has repeatedly pulled at her hair over the past month. The patient's mother says, "My daughter used to say 'mama' and 'papa' and babble away but has begun to talk less in the past few months. She's also become more needy, wanting me to feed her rather than using a spoon herself". Medical history is significant for 3 ear infections in the past year and another seizure thought to have been febrile in origin. Family history is significant for early-onset Alzheimer disease in the patient's paternal grandfather and retinoblastoma in a paternal cousin. The patient is afebrile, and other vital signs are normal. On physical examination, the patient makes eye contact with the physician but speaks no words. She is noted to have a lurching gait. Which of the following would most likely establish a diagnosis in this patient?
questions.explanation: Ans. A) DNA analysis

questions.text: A 63-year-old man with atherosclerotic heart disease has increasing lethargy for the past 5 years. On examination, his blood pressure is 160/110 mm Hg. Laboratory studies show serum creatinine of 6 mg/dL and urea nitrogen of 64 mg/dL. He has the microscopic appearance in his kidneys seen here. Which of the following findings on urinalysis is most specific for the underlying disease leading to this appearance?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Microalbuminuria

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective here is to understand the importance of microalbuminuria as a specific marker for underlying kidney disease, particularly in the context of hypertension-related kidney damage, such as hypertensive nephropathy. Microalbuminuria refers to the presence of small amounts of albumin (a protein) in the urine and is often an early sign of kidney damage. It is specific to renal pathology and can indicate underlying conditions such as hypertensive nephropathy, diabetic nephropathy, or other kidney diseases. In this case, the patient's elevated blood pressure and atherosclerotic heart disease increase the likelihood of hypertensive nephropathy as the underlying cause of his kidney damage, making microalbuminuria a relevant and specific finding on urinalysis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to a sudden onset of severe pain in her left eye with blurred vision, nausea, and vomiting. The symptoms began a few minutes ago, while she was watching a movie in a nearby theatre. Her temperature is 36.8⁰C (98.4⁰F), blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg, pulse is 82/min, and respirations are 14/min. Examination reveals decreased visual acuity. Her left eye appears red, with a hazy cornea, shallow anterior chamber, and dilated, fixed pupil. Her left eye is stony hard to touch. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Acute angle closure glaucoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The critical point here is recognizing the signs and symptoms of acute angle closure glaucoma, a true eye emergency. It's characterized by a sudden increase in intraocular pressure resulting in severe eye pain, redness, blurred vision, a hazy cornea, and a dilated, non-reactive pupil. Immediate medical intervention is necessary to prevent irreversible damage to the optic nerve and permanent vision loss.

options.label: B

questions.text: A 46-year-old man visited his primary care physician one month ago because of chest pain that he had experienced four times in the past four months. The onset of the pain is sudden and radiates to his left jaw. He has experienced this pain while watching television but has never felt it during exercise. During last month’s visit, the physician prescribed sublingual nitroglycerin, and the patient reports that this has shortened the duration of his episodes. Last month’s ECG is shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s chest pain?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Prinzmetal’s angina

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective is to familiarize individuals with the different potential causes of chest pain, emphasizing the need for clinical evaluation, ECG interpretation, and diagnostic tests to determine the underlying etiology.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman visits her gynaecologist for a routine check-up and to discuss birth control options. She expresses interest in combined oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) but is also curious about their additional health benefits beyond contraception. The gynaecologist explains that combined OCPs not only prevent pregnancy but also offer several other health advantages. Based on current medical knowledge, which of the following benefits can be attributed to the use of combined oral contraceptive pills? Reduction in the risk of hepatocellular adenoma Decreased risk of Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID) Prevention of ovarian cysts Alleviation of symptoms of fibrocystic breast disease Lowered risk of ectopic pregnancy
questions.explanation: Ans. C) 2, 3, 4, and 5

questions.text: A 67-year-old man previously diagnosed with Hodgkin lymphoma complains of severe shortness of breath when he walks or climbs stairs. Examination reveals regular venous pressure of 18 cmH2O, bi-basilar rales, an S3 gallop, and 2+ lower-extremity edema. His physician suspects an adverse effect of treatment is causing this patient’s symptoms. The pharmacologic agent most likely responsible for the symptoms in this patient has the same mechanism of action as which of the following cancer drugs?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Doxorubicin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective is to recognize the cardiotoxic effects of chemotherapeutic agents, particularly doxorubicin, an anthracycline antibiotic. Doxorubicin's mechanism of action involves intercalation into DNA and inhibition of topoisomerase II, leading to DNA damage and cell death. However, its use is limited by its dose-dependent cardiotoxicity, which can manifest as acute changes or chronic cardiomyopathy. Recognizing the signs and symptoms of cardiotoxicity in patients previously treated with doxorubicin is crucial for timely management and intervention.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male from Delhi with a history of untreated HIV presents to the clinic with a two-week history of headache, fever, and neck stiffness. On examination, he is found to have photophobia and a positive Brudzinski's sign. A lumbar puncture is performed, and the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) shows an elevated protein level with a low glucose concentration. India has a high prevalence of tuberculosis; however, fungal infections are also considered in differential diagnosis due to his immunocompromised state. Which of the following tests would most likely identify the causative agent in this patient's CSF?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) India ink preparation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The appropriate diagnostic tests for identifying infectious agents in the CSF of an immunocompromised patient is India ink preparation. India ink preparation is a specific test for Cryptococcus neoformans, which is a common cause of meningitis in HIV/AIDS patients.
  • ➤ The appropriate diagnostic tests for identifying infectious agents in the CSF of an immunocompromised patient is India ink preparation.
  • ➤ India ink preparation is a specific test for Cryptococcus neoformans, which is a common cause of meningitis in HIV/AIDS patients.

Which method should the forensic team use to confirm the presence of blood in both the recent and older stains on the clothing?

questions.text: A 45-year-old shepherd presents with persistent abdominal pain and unintentional weight loss. He reports frequent contact with dogs on his farm. An ultrasound of his abdomen shows multiple cystic lesions in the liver. Blood tests reveal eosinophilia. Considering his occupational history and clinical presentation, the location of the adult worms of the parasite causing his condition needs to be identified. What can be the potential location of the adult worms of the parasite in this case?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Dog’s intestine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ​​Dogs serve as the definitive hosts for these parasites, harbouring the adult worms in their intestines. Humans, as intermediate hosts, can develop cystic echinococcosis (hydatid disease), primarily in the liver, after ingesting eggs from the faeces of infected dogs. This is consistent with the patient's condition, where liver cysts were observed.
  • ➤ ​​Dogs serve as the definitive hosts for these parasites, harbouring the adult worms in their intestines.
  • ➤ Humans, as intermediate hosts, can develop cystic echinococcosis (hydatid disease), primarily in the liver, after ingesting eggs from the faeces of infected dogs.
  • ➤ This is consistent with the patient's condition, where liver cysts were observed.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman comes to the primary care office because she has had worsening numbness and tingling in her right hand over the past four months. During the past week, she also has had shooting pains from the wrist to the hand that wakens her from sleep. On physical examination, results of Phalen and Tinel tests are positive. Which of the following studies of the wrists and hands is most appropriate to confirm the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Nerve conduction studies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nerve conduction studies are the most appropriate diagnostic test for confirming carpal tunnel syndrome, as they specifically assess the function of the median nerve and can quantify the degree of nerve impairment. This helps in distinguishing carpal tunnel syndrome from other conditions that might cause similar symptoms.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe chest pain radiating to his back. The pain started 2 hours ago while he was watching television. His medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. On examination, his blood pressure is 210/120 mmHg, heart rate is 98 bpm, and respiratory rate is 20 breaths per minute. His physical examination is unremarkable except for mild tenderness over the chest wall. No murmurs, rubs, or gallops are noted on auscultation. Electrocardiogram (ECG) shows no abnormalities. A chest radiograph is ordered. Which of the following findings on the chest radiograph is most likely in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Widened mediastinum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective is to recognize the classic presentation and radiographic findings of aortic dissection. A widened mediastinum on chest radiograph is a key finding that should raise suspicion for aortic dissection in patients presenting with sudden onset severe chest pain, especially when the pain radiates to the back and is accompanied by significant hypertension.

options.text: The statement X is false, the statement Y is true

options.label: C
options.text: Both the statements X and Y are true

options.label: D
options.text: Both the statements X and Y are false

questions.correct_answer: D. Both the statements X and Y are false
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Both the statements X and Y are false

questions.text: A 30-year-old man has noted a progressively worsening cough for one month. On physical examination, a few small lymph nodes are palpable in his axillae, and the tip of the spleen is palpable. Laboratory studies show Hb of 10.2 g/dL, HCT of 31.1%, MCV of 90 fL, WBC count of 67,400/microliter, and platelet count of 36,220/microliter. His peripheral blood smear is shown here. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Acute myelogenous leukemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective here is to recognize the characteristic features of AML on peripheral blood smear, including the presence of myeloblasts. AML is a type of acute leukemia that involves the proliferation of immature myeloid cells, and identifying these cells in the peripheral blood smear is crucial for diagnosing the condition. Understanding the different types of leukemias and their associated blood smear findings is essential for accurate diagnosis and appropriate management.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man is thrown from a motorcycle. He is taken to the emergency department, where he is alert and awake but in severe pain. On physical examination, he has very limited abduction of his left shoulder and flexion of his left elbow. On observation, the left shoulder is externally rotated. His forearm is pronated, and his elbow is extended. Which of the following muscles is most likely paralyzed in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Teres minor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To recognize the clinical findings associated with Erb's palsy, a brachial plexus injury, and understand which muscles are typically affected by this condition. Healthcare professionals should be able to differentiate between different nerve injuries and their associated muscle deficits to provide appropriate diagnosis and treatment.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by ambulance after she sustained an injury to the right knee while rollerblading. The patient says she felt sudden, severe pain in the knee when she turned a corner quickly. She fell to the ground and was unable to bear weight on the right leg. Physical examination shows swelling and deformity of the right knee as well as inability to fully extend and straighten the right lower extremity. X-ray studies show dislocation of the patella. In addition to administration of analgesics, which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.correct_answer: C. Closed reduction of the patella
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Closed reduction of the patella

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For acute patellar dislocation, closed reduction is the initial management of choice. Surgical interventions are typically reserved for cases where closed reduction is unsuccessful or for recurrent dislocations. Early and appropriate management is crucial for minimizing discomfort and preventing further injury.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with a history of hypertension presents to the clinic with concerns about high blood pressure and fluid retention. During the evaluation, the healthcare provider discusses the role of Atrial Natriuretic Peptide (ANP) in regulating Blood Pressure. What will be the effect of Atrial Natriuretic Peptide on the Mesangial Cells?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Mesangial Relaxation

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ANP's primary effect on mesangial cells is to promote their relaxation , which, in turn, leads to increased GFR and helps maintain fluid and electrolyte balance in the body .

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman has been a cigarette smoker since the age of 18, averaging a pack a day of unfiltered cigarettes. She works as a dispatcher for a trucking company. She has had several episodes of hemoptysis in the past two weeks along with fatigue, headache, nausea, and anorexia. On physical examination, her sensorium is clouded. A chest radiograph shows an ill-defined hilar mass. A transbronchial lung biopsy is performed and the microscopic appearance is shown here. Which of the following laboratory test findings is most likely to be present in this woman?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hyponatremia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To emphasize the association between small cell lung cancer and the Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone (SIADH), which can lead to hyponatremia. Understanding the relationship between certain cancers and paraneoplastic syndromes is crucial for clinical diagnosis and management. Additionally, it's important to be aware that laboratory findings can provide valuable diagnostic clues when evaluating patients with suspected cancer-related complications.
  • ➤ To emphasize the association between small cell lung cancer and the Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone (SIADH), which can lead to hyponatremia. Understanding the relationship between certain cancers and paraneoplastic syndromes is crucial for clinical diagnosis and management. questions.text: A 70-year-old man with coronary artery disease comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. He is 183 cm (6 ft) tall and weighs 84 kg (185 lb); BMI is 25 kg/m 2 . His blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no point of maximal impulse. Serum studies show a glucose concentration of 95 mg/dL and homocysteine concentration of 19.3 μmol/L (N= 5-15). Serum lipid concentrations are within the reference range. Which of the following amino acids is most likely to be decreased in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Methionine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective here is to understand the relationship between amino acids, specifically methionine, and homocysteine metabolism. Recognizing that deficiencies in methionine or cofactors like folate and vitamin B12 can lead to elevated homocysteine levels is important for understanding the underlying mechanisms of hyperhomocysteinemia and its potential cardiovascular implications. Monitoring and managing homocysteine levels can be a part of cardiovascular risk assessment and prevention.
  • ➤ The educational objective here is to understand the relationship between amino acids, specifically methionine, and homocysteine metabolism.
  • ➤ Recognizing that deficiencies in methionine or cofactors like folate and vitamin B12 can lead to elevated homocysteine levels is important for understanding the underlying mechanisms of hyperhomocysteinemia and its potential cardiovascular implications.
  • ➤ Monitoring and managing homocysteine levels can be a part of cardiovascular risk assessment and prevention.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man with a 32-pack-year smoking history presents to his physician because of a 3-month history of productive cough. He is diagnosed with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease after x-ray of the chest demonstrates hyperinflated lungs and a flattened diaphragm. The physician prescribes inhaled steroids, a β2- agonist, and ipratropium bromide. Ipratropium bromide will produce bronchodilation through which of the following mechanisms?

options.label: A
options.text: Blockade of acetylcholine at muscarinic receptors

options.label: B
options.text: Inhibition of phosphodiesterase resulting in increased cAMP levels

options.label: C
options.text: Inhibition of the degranulation of mast cells

options.label: D
options.text: Stimulation of adenylyl cyclase resulting in increased cAMP levels

questions.correct_answer: A. Blockade of acetylcholine at muscarinic receptors
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Blockade of acetylcholine at muscarinic receptors

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective is to understand the mechanism of action of ipratropium bromide in the treatment of COPD. Ipratropium bromide is an anticholinergic agent that works by blocking muscarinic receptors in the airways, preventing acetylcholine-induced bronchoconstriction and leading to bronchodilation. This mechanism is distinct from other bronchodilators, such as beta-2 agonists, which work by stimulating adenylyl cyclase to increase cAMP levels.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with a history of HIV presents with white, corrugated, non-removable lesions along the lateral borders of his tongue (as shown in image). These lesions are asymptomatic and were noted incidentally during a routine dental examination. Which of the following is most commonly associated with this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ EBV causes oral hairy leukoplakia, an opportunistic infection seen in immunocompromised patients, especially those with HIV, characterized by white patches on the lateral aspect of the tongue.
  • ➤ EBV causes oral hairy leukoplakia, an opportunistic infection seen in immunocompromised patients, especially those with HIV, characterized by white patches on the lateral aspect of the tongue.

questions.text: Which method is not typically used to determine the minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) of an antibiotic?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Disk diffusion method

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ MIC can be determined by Gradient diffusion method, Broth micro dilution method and Agar dilution method.
  • ➤ MIC can be determined by Gradient diffusion method, Broth micro dilution method and Agar dilution method.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of acne. The patient has seen several doctors over the past few years for his "huge pimples" and has tried multiple non-prescription acne preparations without benefit. He spends hours a day checking his skin in the mirror for new pimples and scars and researching the latest acne treatments. He avoids socializing and dating due to fears of being rejected based on his appearance. The patient purposely styles his hair to conceal his forehead and cheeks. He has no medical history. Vital signs are within normal limits. The patient is wearing a baseball cap and hesitantly removes it. Physical examination shows a small papule on his forehead and a few closed comedones on his nose that are noticeable only on close inspection. His skin is otherwise clear without scarring or hyperpigmentation. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Reassure patient and schedule regular follow-up

questions.explanation: Ans. D) Start escitalopram

questions.text: A 27-year-old female with no history of medical, ocular, or neurologic problems presents with pain on ocular rotation of the left eye, a mild visual loss for 4 days, decreased visual acuity of 6/9 OS, and a mild sense of colours being washed out in the left eye. Aside from mild relative central scotoma in the left eye and a left relative afferent pupillary defect (0.6 lac units), examination results are normal (All OD results are normal). She is not very bothered by her symptoms. Which of the following is the most appropriate strategy?

options.label: A
options.text: Prompt, high-dose (1 g/day) IV corticosteroid therapy is indicated to preserve vision.

options.label: B
options.text: Oral prednisolone (1 mg/kg) is started till the investigation reports are awaited.

options.label: C
options.text: Visual prognosis remains poor, regardless of intervention.

options.label: D
options.text: One should wait till visual acuity falls below 6/18, before planning any intervention.

questions.correct_answer: A. Prompt, high-dose (1 g/day) IV corticosteroid therapy is indicated to preserve vision.
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Prompt, high-dose (1 g/day) IV corticosteroid therapy is indicated to preserve vision

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl with no significant medical history presents with a five-month history of persistent weakness despite taking vitamins and supplements. Physical examination is completely benign, with normal blood pressure and no peripheral edema. Laboratory studies show hyponatremia, hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, and an increased plasma renin level. Renal biopsy reveals juxtaglomerular cell hyperplasia. Which of the following diuretics acts at the same location as the defect in the patient’s syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Furosemide

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective is to understand the pathophysiology of Bartter syndrome and its similarity to the action of loop diuretics like furosemide. Both Bartter syndrome and furosemide affect the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, leading to similar electrolyte disturbances and metabolic alkalosis. Recognizing the similarities between the effects of certain diuretics and inherited tubulopathies can aid in understanding the underlying mechanisms of these conditions.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents at 10 weeks pregnant. She is a renal transplant recipient and had a transplant 3 years earlier. On examination, her BP is 130/ 80 mmHg. The ultrasound shows a single live fetus of 10 weeks. Which of the following is incorrect regarding pregnancy in a renal transplant patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Women with solid organ transplant have higher severe maternal morbidity rates

options.label: B
options.text: There is an increased incidence of pre-eclampsia

options.label: C
options.text: A rise in serum creatinine levels in pregnancy could be a sign of acute rejection

options.label: D
options.text: The rates of caesarean section are not higher in women with transplanted kidneys

questions.correct_answer: D. The rates of caesarean section are not higher in women with transplanted kidneys
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) The rates of caesarean section are not higher in women with transplanted kidneys

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ PREGNANCY IN WOMEN WITH RENAL TRANSPLANT
  • ➤ PREGNANCY IN WOMEN WITH RENAL TRANSPLANT
  • ➤ Women with solid organ transplant have higher severe maternal morbidity rates. Close surveillance is necessary. Asymptomatic bacteriuria is treated, and if it is recurrent, suppressive treatment is given for the remainder of the pregnancy. Serial hepatic enzyme concentrations and blood counts are monitored for toxic effects of azathioprine and cyclosporine (if the patient is on these drugs). Gestational diabetes is more common if corticosteroids are taken. Preeclampsia is more common. Surveillance for opportunistic infections from herpesvirus, cytomegalovirus, and toxoplasmosis is important because these infections are common. Renal function is monitored, and the GFR usually increases 20 to 25 percent. If a significant rise in the serum creatinine level is detected, its cause must be determined. Possibilities include: Acute rejection Cyclosporine toxicity Preeclampsia Infection Urinary tract obstruction Evidence of pyelonephritis or graft rejection should prompt admission for aggressive management. Imaging studies and kidney biopsy may be indicated. The woman is carefully monitored for development or worsening of underlying hypertension, and especially of superimposed preeclampsia. Vigilant fetal surveillance is indicated because of the higher incidences of fetal-growth restriction and preterm delivery. Although cesarean delivery is reserved for obstetrical indications, occasionally the transplanted kidney obstructs labor, and the overall cesarean delivery rate approaches 80 percent.
  • ➤ Women with solid organ transplant have higher severe maternal morbidity rates.
  • ➤ Close surveillance is necessary.
  • ➤ Asymptomatic bacteriuria is treated, and if it is recurrent, suppressive treatment is given for the remainder of the pregnancy.
  • ➤ Serial hepatic enzyme concentrations and blood counts are monitored for toxic effects of azathioprine and cyclosporine (if the patient is on these drugs).

  • ➤ Surveillance for opportunistic infections from herpesvirus, cytomegalovirus, and toxoplasmosis is important because these infections are common.
  • ➤ Renal function is monitored, and the GFR usually increases 20 to 25 percent.
  • ➤ If a significant rise in the serum creatinine level is detected, its cause must be determined. Possibilities include: Acute rejection Cyclosporine toxicity Preeclampsia Infection Urinary tract obstruction
