questions.text: A 63-year-old man is seen by his doctor after measuring his blood pressure at home and finding it to be 168/100 mm Hg. The patient is concerned because he has had high blood pressure for the past 12 months that has not improved with dietary changes, exercise, or medication. A physical examination is unremarkable except for a thrill heard when auscultating the abdomen just to the left of the midline. What is the most likely cause of the patient’s hypertension?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Elevated levels of aldosterone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective is to understand the role of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system in secondary hypertension, particularly in the context of renal artery stenosis. Renal artery stenosis can lead to activation of the RAAS, resulting in elevated levels of aldosterone and subsequent sodium and water retention, which contributes to hypertension. Identifying physical examination findings, such as an abdominal thrill, can be crucial in suspecting and diagnosing renal artery stenosis as the underlying cause of secondary hypertension.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man has a restricted diet that includes no fresh citrus fruits or leafy green vegetables. His teeth are loose and his gums bleed easily. This patient’s disorder most likely results from a defect in collagen synthesis that involves which of the following amino acids?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hydroxyproline

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective here is to understand the role of vitamin C (ascorbic acid) in collagen synthesis. Vitamin C is essential for the hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues in collagen, particularly for the formation of hydroxyproline. A deficiency in vitamin C leads to the clinical manifestations of scurvy, which is characterized by impaired collagen synthesis and structural abnormalities in connective tissues.
  • ➤ The educational objective here is to understand the role of vitamin C (ascorbic acid) in collagen synthesis. Vitamin C is essential for the hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues in collagen, particularly for the formation of hydroxyproline. A deficiency in vitamin C leads to the clinical manifestations of scurvy, which is characterized by impaired collagen synthesis and structural abnormalities in connective tissues.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man with a stab wound to the abdomen is taken to surgery. While repairing the small intestine, the surgeon notices the presence of a 1 cm circumscribed submucosal mass in the ileum. The lesion is resected and on gross examination, has a firm, yellow-tan cut surface. Microscopically, the mass is composed of nests of cells with uniform small round nuclei and cytoplasm with small purple granules. The cytoplasm is positive with antibody to chromogranin on immunohistochemical staining. Which of the following pathologic findings is most likely to accompany this man’s lesion?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Another similar lesion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective here is to understand the typical characteristics and distribution of neuroendocrine tumors (carcinoid tumors). Carcinoid tumors can occur at various sites along the gastrointestinal tract, and it is not uncommon for patients with one carcinoid tumor to develop another lesion in a different location within the GI tract. Recognizing this pattern can aid in the diagnosis and management of patients with carcinoid tumors.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman presented with headaches for the past month. On physical examination, she has no abnormal findings. A lumbar puncture is performed and examination of the CSF shows a protein of 82 mg/dL, glucose of 58 mg/dL (serum glucose of 74 mg/dL), and cell count with 2 mononuclear leukocytes/microliter. A head CT scan shows a discrete mass beneath the dura compressing the underlying right parietal region. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Meningioma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Meningiomas are slow-growing tumors that arise from the meninges and are often located beneath the dura mater. They can cause symptoms due to compression of adjacent brain tissue, including headaches. Meningiomas are typically benign tumors and are common in adults.
  • ➤ Meningiomas are slow-growing tumors that arise from the meninges and are often located beneath the dura mater.
  • ➤ They can cause symptoms due to compression of adjacent brain tissue, including headaches.
  • ➤ Meningiomas are typically benign tumors and are common in adults.

questions.text: A recent study investigated the relationship between maternal hypertension and the incidence of Intrauterine Growth Restriction (IUGR) in fetuses. The study reported an Odd’s Ratio (OR) of 1:5 for the likelihood of developing an IUGR fetus in the presence of maternal hypertension. How should this finding be interpreted in terms of the association between maternal hypertension and IUGR?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Inverse association

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Interpretation of Odds ratios (OR) is similar to Relative risk (RR) in cohort study (as OR is an estimate of RR). OR > 1: Cases have so-many times higher odds than controls of having the history of exposure under study. OR = 1: Cases have equal odds as controls of having the history of exposure under study; thus exposure IS NOT ASSOCIATED with disease under study. OR < 1: Cases have so-many times lesser odds as controls of having the history of exposure under study; thus exposure IS PROTECTIVE for the disease under study.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with fever, myalgia, and a severe headache. He reports that these symptoms started a few days ago and have progressively worsened. His medical history is unremarkable except for frequent camping trips in wooded areas. On physical examination, he is noted to have a high fever, and laboratory tests reveal elevated liver enzymes. The patient mentions that he noticed several rodents around his camping site during his most recent trip. The emergency physician is considering various differential diagnoses based on the patient's symptoms and history of potential exposure to wildlife. Which of the following diseases is least likely to be associated with the patient’s recent exposure to rodents?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Oriental sore

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ DISEASES ASSOCIATED WITH RODENTS
  • ➤ DISEASES ASSOCIATED WITH RODENTS

questions.text: In a patient with venous ulcer, the following components are used in the management except?
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Anticoagulation

questions.text: A patient comes 6 hours after consuming morphine and presents with pinpoint pupils and respiratory depression. The half-life of morphine is 3 hours and Volume of distribution (Vd) is 200 L. Plasma concentration of morphine at this time is 0.5 microgram/ml. Calculate the initial morphine dose consumed.
questions.explanation: Ans. B) 400 mg

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to the pediatrician due to persistent diarrhea and failure to thrive. On examination, the infant appears to be malnourished with signs of fat malabsorption. Blood tests reveal a notable absence of cholesterol and triglycerides. Lipoprotein electrophoresis shows the absence of both VLDL and LDL fractions. Further microscopic examination of a blood sample indicates the presence of acanthocytes. Based on these findings, the pediatrician believes that a deficiency in a specific protein involved in lipid metabolism may be the underlying cause. Genetic sequencing of which of the following genes is most likely to confirm the pediatrician's suspicion?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Microsomal triglyceride transfer protein

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective is to gain an understanding of abetalipoproteinemia, recognizing its genetic underpinning with mutations in the microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTP) gene. Students should have ability to differentiate abetalipoproteinemia from other lipid metabolism disorders by correlating clinical manifestations and laboratory results.
  • ➤ The educational objective is to gain an understanding of abetalipoproteinemia, recognizing its genetic underpinning with mutations in the microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTP) gene.
  • ➤ Students should have ability to differentiate abetalipoproteinemia from other lipid metabolism disorders by correlating clinical manifestations and laboratory results.

questions.text: A 77-year-old man is referred to the clinic by his primary care provider because he has pain in his left shoulder that has been worsening over the past six months. The patient says the pain has progressed to the extent that he can no longer play golf or enjoy his hobby of cabinet making. He has been treated with one injection of a corticosteroid and has been compliant with physical therapy for the past three months, but he has not had significant relief of his pain. He has no history of injury to the shoulder. On physical examination, range of motion of the shoulder shows forward flexion and abduction to 75 degrees. X-ray study of the shoulder is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient's condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Reverse total arthroplasty of the shoulder

options.label: D
options.text: Open repair of the rotator cuff

questions.correct_answer: B. Reverse total arthroplasty of the shoulder
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Reverse total arthroplasty of the shoulder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In elderly patients with severe shoulder pain, limited range of motion, and failure to respond to conservative treatment, reverse total arthroplasty is often the most effective management, particularly in the presence of severe arthritis and/or significant rotator cuff pathology. This procedure can provide substantial pain relief and functional improvement, especially in those with complex shoulder conditions.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents to the clinic complaining of several painless ulcers on her genitalia. She reports a new sexual partner 2 months ago but cannot provide his medical history. Physical examination reveals multiple, shallow ulcers with a non-purulent base on the labia majora and no inguinal lymphadenopathy. A dark field examination of the ulcer exudate is planned. What organism, seen under dark field microscopy (image below), would be diagnostic in this case?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Treponema pallidum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Primary syphilis is diagnosed by identifying Treponema pallidum in ulcer exudate using dark field microscopy.
  • ➤ Primary syphilis is diagnosed by identifying Treponema pallidum in ulcer exudate using dark field microscopy.

questions.text: A toxicologist is reviewing laboratory reports for patients suspected of lead poisoning. To confirm the diagnosis and assess the severity of lead exposure, the toxicologist refers to specific biomarkers and their critical levels. Match the following biomarkers with their respective critical levels that are indicative of lead poisoning.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) a-iii, b-ii, c-iv, d-i

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A useful screening test is Coproporphyrin in Urine (CPU). Lead Poisoning is known as ‘ Plumbism’ , Saturnism or Painter’s Colic. questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes to her physician complaining of pain with intercourse and dysmenorrhea that worsens one-two days before her period starts. Ultrasonography reveals unilateral adnexal masses, and laparoscopy shows reddish-brown cysts on the ovaries. This patient is at increased risk for developing which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Infertility

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective is to recognize that endometriosis, characterized by the presence of endometrial-like tissue outside the uterus, can lead to significant reproductive morbidity, including infertility. Understanding the implications of endometriosis on fertility and the typical presentations of the disease is crucial for timely diagnosis and management.

questions.text: After four days of flu-like symptoms, a patient is feeling unsteady on her feet and dizzy when she attempts to stand up. During her illness, she has eaten very little and has had frequent emesis. Blood tests reveal an arterial pH of 7.5 and a partial pressure of carbon dioxide of 53 mmHg. What is the most likely etiology of this acid-base disturbance?

options.label: B
options.text: Decreased hydrogen excretion in the distal tubule

options.label: C
options.text: Increased bicarbonate reabsorption by the proximal tubule

options.label: D
options.text: Volume depletion and increased hydrogen excretion in the distal tubule

questions.correct_answer: D. Volume depletion and increased hydrogen excretion in the distal tubule
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Volume depletion and increased hydrogen excretion in the distal tubule

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective is to understand the mechanisms by which vomiting can lead to metabolic alkalosis. Vomiting causes loss of hydrochloric acid from the stomach, resulting in an increase in blood bicarbonate levels and subsequent metabolic alkalosis. Volume depletion due to vomiting and reduced oral intake enhances renal bicarbonate reabsorption and hydrogen ion excretion, further contributing to the alkalosis.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man has complained of heartburn for the past 5 months. On physical examination, there are no abnormal findings. Upper GI endoscopy is performed. Biopsies are taken of an erythematous area of the lower esophageal mucosa. There is no mass lesion and no hemorrhage. The biopsies have the microscopic appearance shown here. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Epithelial metaplasia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Barrett's esophagus is a condition in which there is a metaplastic change in the lower esophageal mucosa, with replacement of squamous epithelium by columnar epithelium containing goblet cells. It is considered a premalignant condition because it increases the risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma. Patients with chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) are at an increased risk of developing Barrett's esophagus.
  • ➤ Barrett's esophagus is a condition in which there is a metaplastic change in the lower esophageal mucosa, with replacement of squamous epithelium by columnar epithelium containing goblet cells.
  • ➤ It is considered a premalignant condition because it increases the risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma.
  • ➤ Patients with chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) are at an increased risk of developing Barrett's esophagus.

questions.text: A 6-month-old male infant is brought to the pediatrician by his concerned parents. They report that their child has been experiencing developmental delays and has had episodes of seizures. On physical examination, the infant displays sparse, coarse, and steely hair, along with pale skin. Additionally, there are signs of temperature dysregulation and difficulty in maintaining body warmth. Laboratory investigations reveal decreased levels of copper and ceruloplasmin in the blood but elevated copper levels in the intestinal biopsy. Based on these findings, which genetic mutation is most likely responsible for the infant's condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Mutation in a chloride channel gene leading to chloride build up in sweat ducts.

options.label: B
options.text: Mutation in a gene coding for an ATPase pump responsible for copper transport.

options.label: C
options.text: Mutation causing the accumulation of phenylalanine due to enzyme deficiency.

options.label: D
options.text: Mutation causing deficient synthesis of collagen fibres.

questions.correct_answer: B. Mutation in a gene coding for an ATPase pump responsible for copper transport.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The objective is to gain insight into Menke’s disease, recognizing its characteristic clinical features such as developmental delays, seizures, sparse and steely hair, pale skin, and temperature dysregulation. They should know how to associate these symptoms with a genetic mutation in the ATP7A gene, which codes for a copper-transporting ATPase pump. This understanding emphasizes the importance of copper transport in various tissues and the consequences of its deficiency in neurological and connective tissue function.
  • ➤ The objective is to gain insight into Menke’s disease, recognizing its characteristic clinical features such as developmental delays, seizures, sparse and steely hair, pale skin, and temperature dysregulation.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement about hydatid cyst disease in humans.

options.label: A
options.text: According to WHO classification, type 1 hydatid cysts are inactive.

options.label: B
options.text: Elective clinical presentation is usually in the form of a lump arising from the liver.

options.label: C
options.text: Anaphylactic shock due to rupture of the hydatid cyst is the emergency presentation.

options.label: D
options.text: CT scan is the diagnostic test.

questions.correct_answer: A. According to WHO classification, type 1 hydatid cysts are inactive.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) According to WHO classification, type 1 hydatid cysts are inactive.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The WHO Informal Working Group on Echinococcosis (WHO-IWGE) proposed a standardized ultrasound classification based on the status of activity of the cyst. This is universally accepted, particularly because it helps to decide on the appropriate management. Three groups have been recognized: Group 1: Active group – cysts larger than 2 cm and often fertile. Group 2: Transition group – cysts starting to degenerate and entering a transitional stage because of host resistance or treatment but may contain viable protoscolices. Group 3: Inactive group – degenerated, partially or totally calcified cysts; unlikely to contain viable protoscolices.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a history of stroke and hypertension comes to the emergency department because of a six-hour history of palpitations and light-headedness. He states that he has experienced shorter episodes of palpitations before, but nothing as severe as this. Physical examination reveals an irregular heart rhythm that eventually improves with various atrioventricular node blocking agents. The patient is prescribed a regimen of daily medications including a drug to prevent a potential complication of his condition. Which of the following drugs is most likely prescribed long term to prevent such complications?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Warfarin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective is to recognize that warfarin is often prescribed for long-term anticoagulation in patients with atrial fibrillation to prevent thromboembolic complications, including stroke. Warfarin's mechanism of action as a vitamin K antagonist makes it effective in reducing the risk of clot formation in conditions where there is an increased risk of thrombosis, such as atrial fibrillation.

questions.text: Following a normal pregnancy and labor, a baby is born to a young couple. The baby cries immediately and has Apgar scores of 9 at both one and five minutes. While examining the baby, the pediatrician presents at delivery notes that the baby has ambiguous genitalia and labial fusion. The baby is also hypotensive and hypovolemic. Genotyping reveals a karyotype of 46XX. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient’s physical findings and symptoms?

options.label: D
options.text: Mutation in the androgen receptor gene

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 21 α-Hydroxylase deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective is to recognize the clinical presentation and underlying cause of congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to 21 α-hydroxylase deficiency. This condition is characterized by adrenal hyperplasia, cortisol and often aldosterone deficiency, with consequent virilization in females and adrenal crisis presenting as hypotension and hypovolemia. Understanding the pathophysiology and clinical manifestations of CAH is crucial for timely diagnosis and management.
  • ➤ The educational objective is to recognize the clinical presentation and underlying cause of congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to 21 α-hydroxylase deficiency. This condition is characterized by adrenal hyperplasia, cortisol and often aldosterone deficiency, with consequent virilization in females and adrenal crisis presenting as hypotension and hypovolemia. questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the office to discuss the progestin-releasing intrauterine device. The patient previously used condoms for contraception but is interested in starting a more reliable method. Her menses occur every 8 to 12 weeks, with heavy vaginal bleeding and passage of clots, and she has intermittent light spotting in between. The patient's last menstrual period was 1 week ago. She has no chronic medical conditions and takes no daily medications. The patient was treated for Trichomonas vaginitis at age 16. Her maternal grandmother had metastatic breast cancer in her 70s. Blood pressure is 118/64 mm Hg and pulse is 80/min. BMI is 44 kg/m². Pelvic examination shows a nulliparous cervix with scant physiologic discharge and a small, nontender uterus. Urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is this patient's contraindication to a progestin-releasing intrauterine device?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Menstrual bleeding pattern

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective is to understand that while progestin-releasing IUDs are generally safe and effective for most women, including those with heavy menstrual bleeding, it is important to evaluate and address any underlying causes of abnormal uterine bleeding before IUD placement. Proper evaluation ensures that any significant pathology is not overlooked and that the IUD can be used safely and effectively.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. Further evaluation reveals a disorder affecting the gastrointestinal tract’s motility. One of the key aspects of normal gastrointestinal tract (GIT) motility is the Basal Electrical Rhythm (BER). What is associated with the initiation of the BER in GIT?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cajal’s Cells

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize the role of interstitial cells of Cajal in generating the Basal Electrical Rhythm , critical for coordinating GIT motility .
  • ➤ Recognize the role of interstitial cells of Cajal in generating the Basal Electrical Rhythm , critical for coordinating GIT motility .

  • ➤ interstitial cells

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy presents to the emergency department because of 18 hours of severe vomiting. Arterial blood gas analysis reveals a pH of 7.48, a bicarbonate level of 35 mEq/L, and a partial carbon dioxide pressure of 48 mm Hg. Which of the following best describes the acid-base disturbance occurring in this patient?
questions.correct_answer: D. Metabolic alkalosis with respiratory compensation
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Metabolic alkalosis with respiratory compensation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective is to understand the principles of acid-base disturbances and their compensatory mechanisms. In metabolic alkalosis, the primary disturbance is an increase in bicarbonate, leading to an increase in pH. The body compensates by decreasing respiratory rate or depth to retain CO2, which increases the partial pressure of CO2, helping to mitigate the increase in pH but not completely normalizing it. Recognizing the patterns of ABG changes in different acid-base disturbances is crucial for diagnosis and management.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic because his thinking has been “slow” recently, citing for example, that he has had trouble remembering the names of his friends. The patient also mentions that he has been feeling depressed, and that he has recently lost a significant amount of weight. The patient reports no history of familial illnesses. Physical examination is notable for purplish skin lesions distributed across his torso. CT of the brain shows diffuse volume loss. Which of the following are most consistent with his current presentation?

options.label: B
options.text: High fever, rigidity of the neck, and encapsulated yeasts in cerebrospinal fluid

options.label: C
options.text: Involuntary, dance-like movements of the arms and gross cortical atrophy

options.label: D
options.text: Progressively decreased mental status and amyloid plaque formation in the brain

questions.correct_answer: A. Ataxia, urinary incontinence, and seizures
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ataxia, urinary incontinence, and seizures

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective is to recognize the signs and complications of advanced HIV/AIDS, including CNS manifestations and opportunistic infections. Patients with advanced HIV/AIDS may present with a variety of neurological symptoms due to direct virus effects or secondary to opportunistic infections. Kaposi's sarcoma, a common AIDS-associated neoplasm, can also provide a clue to the underlying immunocompromised state. Understanding the broad range of presentations of HIV/AIDS is crucial for early recognition and appropriate management of these patients.

questions.text: Dr. Kavita, a recent medical school graduate, is attending a workshop on medical law. The presenter discusses a case where a patient alleged civil negligence against a physician, but the lawsuit was not filed within the legally designated period. Dr. Kavita is asked to identify the legal doctrine that bars the case from being opened after this period. Which term correctly identifies this doctrine?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Res indicata

questions.text: During laryngoscopy and endo-tracheal intubation, which of the manoeuvre is not performed?

options.label: B
options.text: Extension of Head at the atlanto-occipital joint

options.label: C
options.text: The laryngoscope is lifted upwards levering over the upper incisors

options.label: D
options.text: In a straight blade laryngoscope, the epiglottis is lifted by the tip

questions.correct_answer: C. The laryngoscope is lifted upwards levering over the upper incisors
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) The laryngoscope is lifted upwards levering over the upper incisors

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key educational objective here is to understand the proper techniques and manoeuvres used during laryngoscopy and endotracheal intubation to ensure a safe and effective procedure. It's important to recognize that proper positioning of the patient's head and neck, the appropriate use of laryngoscope blades, and avoiding harmful practices like levering against the teeth are critical for successful intubation. This knowledge is essential for healthcare professionals involved in airway management, particularly in emergency or surgical settings.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with a history of chronic alcohol abuse presents with confusion and gait disturbances. Neurological examination reveals persistent confusion, memory deficits, dysarthria and difficulty walking. Brain imaging is performed to evaluate the patient's condition. Upon examination, the patient displayed signs of cognitive impairment, gait disturbances, and bilateral upper motor neuron facial palsy. Based on the clinical presentation and imaging findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Marchiafava-Bignami syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key objective of this clinical case is to recognize the clinical presentation and imaging findings that are indicative of Marchiafava-Bignami syndrome. This rare neurological condition is often associated with chronic alcohol abuse and presents with a distinct set of symptoms, including confusion, cognitive impairment, gait disturbances, and, in some cases, upper motor neuron facial palsy. Early diagnosis is crucial for appropriate management and intervention in such cases.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman has the sudden onset of severe headaches. During one of these episodes, her blood pressure is 190/115 mm Hg. Her usual blood pressure is 130/90 mm Hg. Her sister had similar episodes several years ago. Urinalysis shows increased concentrations of metanephrine and vanillylmandelic acid. The patient is most likely to have a neoplasm that secretes which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Epinephrine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective here is to recognize the clinical presentation and hormone secretion associated with pheochromocytomas. These tumors secrete excess catecholamines, including epinephrine and norepinephrine, which can lead to intermittent and severe hypertension, among other symptoms. Early diagnosis and management are essential to prevent potentially life-threatening hypertensive crises.

questions.text: In an emergency department, a physician treats a patient with a severe bacterial infection. The physician notes that certain components of the patient's immune system are facilitating phagocytosis by marking the bacteria for easier identification and engulfment by phagocytes. Which of the following is acting as an opsonin in this scenario?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) C3b

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ C3b, a fragment of the complement protein C3, serves as an opsonin, playing a key role in the immune system by binding to bacteria surfaces and marking them for phagocytosis by neutrophils and macrophages.
  • ➤ C3b, a fragment of the complement protein C3, serves as an opsonin, playing a key role in the immune system by binding to bacteria surfaces and marking them for phagocytosis by neutrophils and macrophages.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents for evaluation of sudden-onset abnormal breathing and shortness of breath. Yesterday morning, the patient developed a runny nose. Over the past 12 hours, he developed fever and has had difficulty breathing. Temperature is 40⁰C (104⁰F) and respiratory rate is 48/min. Pulse oximetry shows 86% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears anxious and is sitting up, leaning forward, and drooling. Inspiratory stridor and suprasternal retractions are present. His lips are mildly cyanotic. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Endotracheal intubation

questions.text: A 67-year-old man has had back pain for the past 9 months. He has had a productive cough for the past 3 days. On physical examination, his temperature is 39°C and there is dullness to percussion at the right lung base. Laboratory studies show 4+ gram-positive diplococci in the sputum. A chest radiograph shows right lower lobe consolidation. An abdominal CT scan shows multiple lytic lesions of the vertebrae. On the day prior to death, his serum urea nitrogen was 63 mg/dL with creatinine 7.1 mg/dL. A dipstick urinalysis was normal. At autopsy, his kidneys are firm and pale. Microscopically, there is abundant pink hyaline material in glomeruli and around small vessels. This material stains positively with Congo red. Which of the following laboratory findings was most likely to have been present in this patient in the week prior to death?
questions.correct_answer: B. Total serum protein of 9.2 g/dL
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Total serum protein of 9.2 g/dL

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective here is to understand the significance of an elevated total serum protein level as a marker of underlying systemic amyloidosis, which can occur in the context of chronic inflammatory conditions or infections. Recognizing the association between elevated total serum protein and amyloidosis can aid in diagnosing this potentially serious condition, which may have a variety of clinical manifestations.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman complaints of alternating bouts of diarrhea and constipation and reports chronic abdominal pain relieved by frequent bowel movements. Her symptoms are exacerbated by stress. The patient denies fever or weight loss. She has a negative fecal occult blood test. Colonoscopy and endoscopy reveal no abnormalities. The most likely diagnosis in this patient is commonly associated with which of the following findings?

options.label: D
options.text: Villous flattening in the small intestine

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Normal biopsy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective is to recognize the clinical presentation and diagnostic criteria of Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS), a functional gastrointestinal disorder characterized by a combination of symptoms like abdominal pain, bloating, and altered bowel habits (diarrhea, constipation, or both) without any underlying organic pathology. Understanding that the diagnosis of IBS is largely clinical and based on symptomatology and exclusion of other organic diseases is crucial for proper management and reassurance of the patient.

On physical examination, her abdominal musculature is rigid, making palpation difficult because of severe tenderness. Laboratory studies show her serum lipase is 1165 U/L. Her total WBC count is 16,390/microliter with 86% granulocytes. The gross appearance of her disease process is shown here. Which of the following is the most probable etiology for this process?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective here is to recognize the clinical presentation and common etiologies of acute pancreatitis. Gallstones are a frequent cause of acute pancreatitis, and understanding this association can aid in the diagnosis and management of patients with acute abdominal pain and pancreatic enzyme abnormalities.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents to the emergency department complaining of diarrhea, heart palpitations, anxiety, and diffuse abdominal pain. Vital signs show tachycardia. The patient wanted to lose weight and started taking her mother’s medication to do so; she does not know for which condition the medication was prescribed. Her friend had similar symptoms not long ago and was treated for her condition. Which of the following most likely accounts for this patient’s presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Levothyroxine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key educational objective here is to recognize the signs and symptoms of thyrotoxicosis (excessive thyroid hormone levels), which can be caused by inappropriate intake of levothyroxine, a medication used to treat hypothyroidism. Understanding the pharmacological profiles and the clinical implications of medications used to manage thyroid disorders is crucial for accurate diagnosis and management.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy with a history of mental retardation and seizures is brought to the physician with a three-month history of worsening of shortness of breath. During physical examination, the physician notices numerous acne-like papules on the patient’s face. Echocardiography shows significant left ventricular outflow obstruction. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient’s heart condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Rhabdomyoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective is to recognize the association between cardiac rhabdomyomas and tuberous sclerosis. Tuberous sclerosis is a genetic disorder that can cause the development of benign tumors in multiple organs, including the brain, skin, and heart. Cardiac rhabdomyomas are often found in patients with tuberous sclerosis and can lead to various cardiac manifestations, including outflow tract obstruction.

questions.text: A pediatrician is evaluating a 2-year-old boy for malnutrition. The child's current weight is 7 kg, and his height is 74 cm. According to standard growth charts, the median expected weight for a child of his height (74 cm) is 9 kg, and the median expected height for his age (2 years) is 86 cm. Utilizing the World Health Organization (WHO) classification for undernutrition, the pediatrician needs to determine the appropriate category for this child's nutritional status. How should this child be classified based on his weight-for-height and height-for-age measurements?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Wasted, stunted

questions.text: A 26-year-old mother of two rushes to her obstetrician’s office at 35 weeks’ gestation because of cramping abdominal pain and mild vaginal bleeding. Both cramps and bleeding started about two hours ago. Pain is constant, with intermittent episodes of severe cramping. Bleeding has been sufficient to soak through four to five pads within the past few hours. She denies a history of trauma or leakage of clear fluid. She does admit to using cocaine three times within the past month, most recently last night. She is afebrile, blood pressure is 155/95 mm Hg, and heart rate is 100/min. Bi-manual examination reveals tenderness over the fundus and a non-dilated cervix. Ultrasound reveals a normally implanted placenta with no visible abnormalities. Fetal heart rate is in the 170-180/min range. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Abruptio placentae

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective is to recognize the clinical presentation and risk factors for placental abruption (abruptio placentae), including abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, uterine tenderness, and fetal distress, especially in the context of known risk factors such as cocaine use and hypertension. It's important to note that the diagnosis can be clinical and may not always be visible on ultrasound.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man is admitted to the hospital for severe shortness of breath. He states that he has been having increased difficulty breathing when performing physical activity. Lung auscultation reveals bilateral crackles. His blood pressure is 125/85 mm Hg, and his heart rate is 86/min. Cardiac auscultation detects no rubs or murmurs. Blood tests are not suggestive of infection. Coronary artery angiography is performed and shows no significant vascular disease. What is the most likely cause of this patient’s disease manifestations?

options.label: C
options.text: Fibrotic debris within the pericardial membrane

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Ventricular dysfunction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective is to familiarize individuals with the different potential causes of severe shortness of breath, emphasizing the need for clinical evaluation and diagnostic tests to determine the underlying etiology.

questions.text: A 70-year-old hypertensive patient with stage 5 chronic kidney disease was diagnosed recently with Type 2 diabetes mellitus. He does not want to take injectable drugs. Which of the following oral hypoglycemic agents will be preferred in this patient that does not require any dose modification in renal failure?

questions.text: During embryonic development of the urinary system, a portion of the bladder extends into the umbilical cord. Failure of this vestigial structure to degenerate may lead to which of the following complications?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understanding the potential complications that can arise from the failure of vestigial structures to degenerate properly during embryonic development. In this case, the focus is on recognizing that persistent embryonic tissue can increase the risk of bladder adenocarcinoma, a type of bladder cancer. Healthcare professionals should be aware of these associations to provide appropriate diagnosis and treatment for their patients.

questions.text: A 5-year girl develops precocious puberty. Gonadotropin levels are low, even following gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) infusion stimulation testing. Estrogen levels are elevated. Which of the following could NOT be a cause of her disorder?
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Pituitary tumor

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman comes to a follow-up appointment complaining of weight gain three weeks after beginning a new medication for her refractory schizophrenia. Laboratory studies show a low WBC count and low absolute neutrophil count. Peripheral blood smear shows a total absence of neutrophils and bands. The rest of the laboratory results are within normal limits. Which of the following drug therapies did this patient most likely begin two weeks ago?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Clozapine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective is to recognize that clozapine, an atypical antipsychotic used for refractory schizophrenia, can cause serious hematological side effects, including agranulocytosis (severe neutropenia), and is also associated with weight gain. This highlights the importance of monitoring blood counts in patients started on clozapine therapy.

questions.text: During a dermatology training session focused on leprosy management, the instructor discusses the criteria for starting Multi-Drug Therapy (MDT). MDT is a critical component in the treatment of leprosy, and its initiation is based on specific clinical and diagnostic criteria. The instructor presents a list of possible criteria and asks the attendees to identify which of these should be satisfied to justify the initiation of MDT. Based on current medical guidelines, which of the following criteria should be met to start MDT for leprosy? Hypopigmented patch with sensory loss Peripheral nerve thickening Peripheral nerve thickening with sensory loss Skin biopsy demonstrating bacilli
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1, 3

Multibacillary leprosy has sensory loss (hypo-anesthesia) and nerve involvement.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the office by his mother because he has had intermittent pain in the right hip during the past two weeks. The patient ambulates with difficulty. He has not had fever, chills, malaise, recent illness, or trauma to the hip. The patient is obese but otherwise healthy. On physical examination, vague pain in the groin is elicited on range of motion of the right hip. The most appropriate next step is x-ray studies to rule out which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Slipped capital femoral epiphysis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When evaluating a child with hip pain, particularly in the context of obesity and no recent trauma, SCFE should be a primary consideration. X-ray studies are crucial in the diagnosis of SCFE, which can have significant implications for the child's mobility and hip joint health if not treated promptly.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with a complaint of dragging his foot while walking. On examination, he demonstrates difficulty in dorsiflexing his foot at the ankle. This clinical presentation is most likely due to a lesion affecting which nerve?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Deep Peroneal (Fibular) Nerve

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 65-year-old retired construction worker who has a history of working in construction and insulation for over 20 years, presents to OPD with complaints of shortness of breath, dry cough, and chest discomfort that have been progressively worsening over the past few years. On physical examination, the physician notes decreased breath sounds in the lower lobes of both lungs and crackles heard on auscultation. Spirometry shows a reduced forced vital capacity (FVC) and forced expiratory volume (FEV1) in 1 second. HRCT done is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Round atelectasis

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital for treatment of pneumococcal pneumonia. Treatment with gentamicin and penicillin is initiated. Within 10 minutes of the administration of antimicrobial therapy, her respiration rate increases to 30/min, and blood pressure decreases to 80/40 mm Hg. Epinephrine, antihistamine, and corticosteroid therapy is started. Her condition improves slowly during the next 2 hours. Her antimicrobial therapy is changed to gentamicin only, and her condition continues to improve. Administration of which of the following types of drugs is most likely to cause a similar adverse reaction in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cephalosporins

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with a history of anaphylactic reactions to penicillin, cephalosporins, the class of antibiotics, are most likely to cause a similar adverse reaction due to structural similarities and potential cross-reactivity. It is important to assess the risk of cross-reactivity when choosing antibiotics for patients with known severe allergies to specific drug classes.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man with no significant past medical history presents to the emergency department with hemoptysis. He has never had an episode like this before. He does recall having a cold approximately three weeks earlier and has been experiencing increased fatigue and breathlessness since then, but he denies any current symptoms of rhinorrhea, sore throat, nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea. X-ray of the chest shows diffuse opacities in both lower lung fields, and urinalysis reveals RBCs in the urine. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Goodpasture syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: During a study on the zoonotic transmission of avian influenza, researchers introduce random mutations into the virus's genome. One mutated strain gained the ability to infect human respiratory epithelial cells. Which viral component's alteration would most likely allow the avian influenza virus to acquire the ability to infect human cells?

Ans. A) Antigenic glycoprotein

Educational Objective:

In the case of influenza viruses, the hemagglutinin (HA) antigenic glycoprotein is crucial for this binding process. Mutations in HA can alter the virus's host specificity, potentially enabling it to infect new species, including humans.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man with hypertension comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. At his last visit 3 months ago, his serum total cholesterol concentration was 320 mg/dL. He then began a low-cholesterol diet. His blood pressure is 145/95 mmHg. Physical examination shows no other abnormalities. Serum studies show a total cholesterol concentration of 310 mg/dL. Kidney and liver function test results are within normal limits. The most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient is a drug that has which of the following mechanisms of action?

options.label: B
options.text: Decreases hepatic production of VLDL cholesterol

options.label: C
options.text: Forms insoluble complexes with bile acids in the gut

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Inhibits 3-HMG-CoA reductase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy for a patient with significantly elevated LDL cholesterol, especially in the context of cardiovascular risk factors such as hypertension, is a statin. Statins work by inhibiting the HMG-CoA reductase enzyme, leading to decreased cholesterol synthesis in the liver and increased clearance of LDL cholesterol from the blood. This mechanism directly addresses the need to lower LDL cholesterol, making it the preferred option in such cases. Other therapies like fibrates, niacin, and bile acid sequestrants have roles in specific lipid abnormalities but are not the first choice for primary LDL reduction.

questions.text: A 49-year-old male, a case of congestive heart failure with elevated liver enzymes and greyish pigmentation of the skin came to the OPD. Final diagnosis of CCF (Congestive Cardiac Failure), hepatitis with cirrhosis of the liver was made. A liver biopsy was done which shows marked increase in iron storage. Which of the following is true regarding molecular iron (Fe)?

options.label: A
options.text: Stored in the spleen and absorbed in the intestine by albumin

options.label: B
options.text: Excreted in the urine as Fe 2+

questions.correct_answer: C. Stored in combination with ferritin

Ans. C) Stored in combination with ferritin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective here is to understand the role of ferritin in storing iron within the body. Ferritin is an essential protein for iron storage, and increased iron storage can occur in conditions like hemochromatosis, which can lead to complications such as liver cirrhosis. Recognizing the importance of iron storage mechanisms in the body is crucial for understanding and managing conditions related to iron overload.
  • ➤ The educational objective here is to understand the role of ferritin in storing iron within the body.
  • ➤ Ferritin is an essential protein for iron storage, and increased iron storage can occur in conditions like hemochromatosis, which can lead to complications such as liver cirrhosis.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman has had episodes of lower abdominal and pelvic pain for the past 11 years. A bimanual pelvic examination reveals no abnormalities. A Pap smear is negative. She has an abdominal ultrasound scan that reveals no abnormalities. She undergoes laparoscopy, and several 0.2 to 0.5 cm brown nodular lesions are seen on serosal surfaces of the uterus, fallopian tubes, and appendix. These lesions are excised. Which of the following microscopic findings is most likely to be present in these lesions?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Endometrial stroma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

Endometriosis is characterized by the presence of endometrial tissue, including endometrial stroma, outside the uterus. Recognizing these histological features is important for diagnosing and managing patients with endometriosis, a common cause of chronic pelvic pain and fertility problems in women.

questions.text: A 19-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department following a bicycle accident. The patient was riding downhill when he hit a rock and lost control. He was thrown off his bicycle and hit the handlebars before tumbling onto the pavement. The patient was not wearing a helmet but did not lose consciousness. Blood pressure is 118/80 mmHg and pulse is 140/min. Examination shows ecchymosis over the right superior orbit with underlying tenderness and a few scalp abrasions. Visual acuity is 20/20 in the left eye. Using the right eye, the patient is unable to read the largest letter on the visual acuity chart and is only able to perceive light. There is a relative afferent pupillary defect in the right eye. Extraocular movements are normal, and the red reflex is symmetric bilaterally. Fluorescein dye testing is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Optic nerve injury

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The key educational point here is recognizing the signs of optic nerve injury, especially in the context of trauma. A relative afferent pupillary defect is a crucial clinical sign indicating potential optic nerve damage. It's important to promptly identify and manage such injuries, as they can have significant implications for a patient's vision and overall ocular health.

questions.text: A clinical study is performed with subjects who developed a skin rash. Skin biopsies from these subjects are analyzed by immunofluoresence. questions.text: A 43-year-old woman comes to the clinic complaining of blurry vision. She states that for the past three weeks, her eyes have been very dry and itchy, and she is unable to make tears. She also states that she has had a very dry mouth despite drinking adequate fluids. Physical examination reveals bilateral dry, ulcerated corneas and fissures on the sides of her lips. In addition, both of her knees are erythematous and swollen. When asked about her knees, she says, “Yes, my knees and wrists tend to be swollen and stiff in the morning, but my mom had arthritis.” Testing for several autoantibodies reveals she is rheumatoid factor-positive and antibody-SS-B (La)-positive. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Sjögren syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective is to recognize the clinical features and diagnostic criteria for Sjögren syndrome, an autoimmune disorder characterized by dry eyes, dry mouth, and other systemic manifestations. The presence of specific autoantibodies, such as rheumatoid factor and anti-SS-B (La), supports the diagnosis. Understanding the multi-systemic nature of Sjögren syndrome is crucial for diagnosis, as it often presents with extra-glandular manifestations such as arthritis.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus and a 30-pound weight loss over the past two months presents to the physician with a history of nausea and bloating. Ans. B) Metoclopramide

Metoclopramide is a prokinetic agent that can improve gastric emptying and reduce symptoms of gastroparesis by enhancing gastrointestinal motility and providing antiemetic effects. It is important to choose treatment options that address the underlying pathophysiology of the condition, which in the case of gastroparesis, involves delayed gastric emptying and impaired motility.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child opened his father’s drawer and ingested multiple tablets of his cardiac medication, metoprolol. The child was brought to hospital with profound hypotension and bradycardia. What is the specific antidote used in this situation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Glucagon

Glucagon can effectively counteract the profound hypotension and bradycardia caused by beta-blocker overdose by stimulating cardiac function through an alternative signalling pathway (CAMP-mediated). It is important for healthcare providers to be aware of the appropriate antidotes and treatments for toxicities caused by various medications, especially in emergency situations involving children.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the office to discuss management of hypertension. She has chronic hypertension, which is managed with a stable dose of chlorthalidone. The patient's mother was diagnosed with hypertension at age 35. Blood pressure is 130/81 mm Hg; repeat blood pressure is 128/77 mm Hg. BMI is 26 kg/m². Physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory results are as follows: Creatinine: 0.8 mg/dL; Potassium: 3.7 mEq/L; Hemoglobin A1c: 5.7%. Which of the following is the best advice for this patient?

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ To recognize that when managing chronic hypertension in a woman planning pregnancy, it is important to use antihypertensive medications that are considered safe during pregnancy. Extended-release nifedipine is a suitable option due to its safety profile in pregnancy, while medications like chlorthalidone and spironolactone should be avoided due to potential risks to the fetus.

  • ➤ It is often associated with exposure to coal dust or environmental pollution.
  • ➤ This condition is important to recognize in occupational and environmental medicine and can mimic other conditions such as lung cancer on imaging.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with chest pain and dyspnoea for 10 days. The chest pain is bilateral, dull, persistent, and not worsened by exertion. The patient's medical history is significant for a normal spontaneous vaginal delivery 3 months ago, after which she had frequent episodes of dark, bloody vaginal discharge. The most recent bleeding episode was 6 days ago. The patient has no fever, chills, hemoptysis, orthopnea, or leg pain. Temperature is 37.5⁰C (99.5⁰F), blood pressure is 110/68 mm Hg, pulse is 80/min, and respirations are 16/min. BMI is 26.2 kg/m². Physical examination reveals bilaterally clear lungs. The extremities are warm and well perfused. There is no peripheral edema. Pelvic examination reveals an enlarged uterus, a closed cervix, and minimal dark blood in the vagina. Complete blood count and serum electrolytes are within normal limits. Chest x-rays reveal multiple bilateral infiltrates of various shapes. Which of the following would be most helpful in establishing this patient's diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Quantitative β-hCG test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key educational objective is to recognize the importance of measuring β-hCG levels in the evaluation of a patient with suspected gestational trophoblastic disease, such as choriocarcinoma, especially when presenting with symptoms consistent with metastasis. Elevated β-hCG levels are a hallmark of trophoblastic diseases and can aid in the diagnosis and monitoring of treatment response.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida woman is in the second stage of labor. The obstetrician determines that an episiotomy is necessary to facilitate the delivery of the baby's head. When performing an episiotomy, which of the following instruments is commonly used?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Braun-Stadler scissors

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ This is a scissors that is characteristically angulated in the middle and very easy to identify. The inside blade is guided by 2 fingers so as to avoid inadvertent injury to the fetus. Episiotomy should NOT be given routinely; rather restrictively in conditions like : Macrosomia Assisted breech delivery Use of instrumental delivery Shoulder dystocia Rigid perineum The layers cut in an episiotomy from inside out are: Vaginal mucosa Muscle (superficial and deep transverse perinei, Bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani) Perineal skin An episiotomy is a type of 2 nd degree perineal tear

questions.text: Which of these intra-venous therapies is preferred while performing damage control resuscitation in traumatic hemorrhage?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Blood products

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ During damage control resuscitation in traumatic hemorrhage, the preferred intravenous therapy is blood products, as they help maintain hemostasis, oxygenation, and coagulation without causing dilutional coagulopathy.
  • ➤ During damage control resuscitation in traumatic hemorrhage, the preferred intravenous therapy is blood products, as they help maintain hemostasis, oxygenation, and coagulation without causing dilutional coagulopathy.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of cystic fibrosis presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of increased sputum production, fever, and a new onset of left lower lobe crackles on auscultation. His sputum culture grows Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Which of the following antibiotics would be most appropriate to treat this infection?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Piperacillin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Piperacillin, broad-spectrum, beta-lactam antibiotics is the optimal choice for treating a pulmonary exacerbation of cystic fibrosis, particularly when Pseudomonas aeruginosa is suspected. Piperacillin is often paired with a beta-lactamase inhibitor like tazobactam to enhance its efficacy.
  • ➤ Piperacillin, broad-spectrum, beta-lactam antibiotics is the optimal choice for treating a pulmonary exacerbation of cystic fibrosis, particularly when Pseudomonas aeruginosa is suspected.
  • ➤ Piperacillin is often paired with a beta-lactamase inhibitor like tazobactam to enhance its efficacy.

questions.text: In a hospital setting, a known HIV positive patient underwent abdominal surgery and was subsequently admitted to an isolation ward. The day after the surgery, a resident doctor changed the patient's dressing and found it heavily soaked in blood. Considering the need for proper disposal of contaminated medical waste, especially in the context of an HIV positive patient, what is the most appropriate method for discarding the blood-soaked dressing?

options.label: A
options.text: Pour 1% hypochlorite on the dressing material and send it for incineration in an appropriate bag

options.label: B
options.text: Pour 5% hypochlorite on the dressing material and send it for incineration in an appropriate bag

options.label: C
options.text: Put the dressing material directly in an appropriate bag and send for incineration

options.label: D
options.text: Pour 2% Lysol on the dressing material and send it for incineration in an appropriate bag

questions.correct_answer: A. Pour 1% hypochlorite on the dressing material and send it for incineration in an appropriate bag
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pour 1% hypochlorite on the dressing material and send it for incineration in an appropriate bag

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ All HIV infected material, i.e. gauge pieces, bandages, cotton swabs, blood units, blood have to be incinerated .
  • ➤ All HIV infected material, i.e. gauge pieces, bandages, cotton swabs, blood units, blood have to be incinerated .

questions.text: A 74-year-old woman comes to the office due to several days of right ear pain. This morning she had 2 episodes of dizziness and almost fell. The patient is currently taking trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for an uncomplicated urinary tract infection. She has had no subjective fever, vision loss, or headaches. Temperature is 37⁰C (98.6⁰F), blood pressure is 116/78 mm Hg, and pulse is 100/min. Ear examination reveals several erythematous vesicles in the right external auditory canal with no drainage. The tympanic membrane is visible and intact. There is mild right-sided facial droop. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable. Which is the most likely cause of this patient's illness?
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Varicella zoster virus

questions.text: In a neonatal intensive care unit (NICU), a healthcare team is caring for a preterm infant whose mother is unable to produce breast milk. The team is considering the best alternative feeding options for the infant to ensure proper nutrition and development. What is the most suitable feeding option for a preterm baby in the absence of maternal breast milk?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Donor mother’s milk

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ If a mother’s own breast milk is not available, the second choice should be donor breast milk. Studies have indicated that donor breast milk has short and long-term benefits as compared to preterm formula (WHO).
  • ➤ If a mother’s own breast milk is not available, the second choice should be donor breast milk.
  • ➤ Studies have indicated that donor breast milk has short and long-term benefits as compared to preterm formula (WHO).

questions.text: A 61-year-old man with a medical history of cancer presents with a two-week history of constant and severe headaches that are most severe when he wakes up in the morning. He also notes changes in vision associated with the headaches. Physical examination shows a healing ecchymotic lesion on the right forearm, papilledema in the left eye, a right-sided pronator drift, and weakness of the right arm. The diagnosis of an intracranial hemorrhage is confirmed with CT of the head. Which of the following cancers is most likely to have resulted in this patient’s presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Melanoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective is to recognize the potential for certain cancers, particularly melanoma, to metastasize to the brain and cause hemorrhagic metastases, leading to acute neurological symptoms. Understanding the patterns of cancer metastasis is crucial for the diagnosis and management of patients presenting with neurological symptoms and a history of cancer.

questions.text: A 56-year-old previously healthy physician notices that his eyes are yellow and he has been losing weight. On physical examination, the patient has jaundice and scleral icterus with a palpable gall bladder lump. Transcutaneous ultrasound of the abdomen demonstrates biliary ductal dilation without gallstones. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the workup of this patient?
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Computed tomography (CT) scan

questions.text: A 9-month-old girl is brought to the clinic for a well-child visit. She was born precipitously at 35 weeks gestation due to preterm labor to a 22-year-old primigravida who did not receive prenatal care. The patient's neonatal course was notable for a 1-week hospital stay due to difficulty feeding. She was hospitalized for bronchiolitis at age of 3 months for 4 days. The patient can crawl but has not begun cruising. She has been babbling and repeating "mama." Height, weight, and head circumference track along the 25th percentile. She is alert and smiling at the examiner and her mother. Ophthalmoscopic examination reveals a white reflex in the left eye and a red reflex in the right. Extraocular movements are intact, and the pupils are equal and reactive to light. The corneal light reflex is symmetric. The remainder of the examination is normal. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's physical examination findings?
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Retinoblastoma

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a recent growth spurt of 15 cm (6 in) during the past year. She also has had increasing fatigue and palpitations during this period. Her paternal aunt has a history of palpitations and severe myopia. She is at the 95th percentile for height and 50th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows a long, thin face. Ophthalmologic examination shows dislocated lenses. Cardiac examination shows a hyperdynamic precordium with early click and systolic murmur. Echocardiography shows an enlarged aortic root and mitral valve prolapse. Abnormal synthesis of which of the following proteins is the most likely cause of this patient’s disorder?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Fibrillin-1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective here is to recognize that Marfan syndrome is primarily caused by mutations in the FBN1 gene, leading to abnormal synthesis of fibrillin-1, a major component of microfibrils in connective tissues. Understanding the genetic and structural protein basis of Marfan syndrome is important for diagnosis and management of this connective tissue disorder, which can affect various organ systems.
  • ➤ The educational objective here is to recognize that Marfan syndrome is primarily caused by mutations in the FBN1 gene, leading to abnormal synthesis of fibrillin-1, a major component of microfibrils in connective tissues.
  • ➤ Understanding the genetic and structural protein basis of Marfan syndrome is important for diagnosis and management of this connective tissue disorder, which can affect various organ systems.
